title: “EE.UU. es un país en búsqueda de un enemigo”: Óscar Arias, premio Nobel de la Paz al que Washington le revocó su visa - (Published 8 hour(s), 4 minute(s) ago)
content: El expresidente de Costa Rica repasa su compleja relación con Washington, desde la tensión con Reagan hasta sus discrepancias con Trump ...
resumen: Óscar Arias, premio Nobel de la Paz y expresidente de Costa Rica, afirma sentirse orgulloso de su vida política. Estados Unidos le revocó su visa de entrada al país, decisión de la cual el gobierno de Donald Trump no ha divulgado el motivo. Arias sospecha que la medida responde a posturas que ha asumido sobre la relación de su país con China, el aumento del gasto militar de EE.UU. y la forma de gobernar de Trump, a quien compara con un emperador romano. Arias fue galardonado con el Nobel de la Paz en 1987 por su contribución para terminar con las guerras civiles en Centroamérica. En su primer gobierno le tocó la pacificación de Centroamérica. En el segundo gobierno la lucha fue para convencer a los costarricenses de que era una locura que Costa Rica se aislara del tratado de libre comercio con EE.UU. En 1986, su relación con el entonces presidente Ronald Reagan fue “muy tensa”. Arias defiende que fue la decisión correcta que Costa Rica estableciera relaciones con China en 2007. Arias considera que EE.UU. es una nación en búsqueda de un enemigo y que la confrontación que plantea con China es un problema grave para el mundo.

title: Cafeterías en EE. UU. golpeadas por fuerte aumento de precios tras aranceles - (Published 19 hour(s), 2 minute(s) ago)
content: El precio de una taza de café en Estados Unidos está en alza debido a la entrada en vigor de aranceles del 10 % sobre importaciones, afectando ...
resumen: El precio de una taza de café en Estados Unidos está en alza debido a la entrada en vigor de aranceles del 10 % sobre importaciones, afectando directamente a pequeños negocios y consumidores en todo el país. Desde el pasado 5 de abril, Estados Unidos impone aranceles del 10 % a las importaciones de café desde la mayoría de los países productores. Esta medida ha impactado de forma inmediata a cafeterías locales, como Bread Bite Bakery en Washington D.C., donde el propietario Jorge Prudencio informó que su distribuidor colombiano ya aumentó los precios. Estados Unidos es el segundo mayor importador de café del mundo, con Brasil y Colombia como principales proveedores. Kamal Mortada, gerente de Au Lait Café, expresó preocupación: “Los precios del menú subieron un 25 % y ahora la gente solo pide café negro. En San Francisco, Jenny Ngo, dueña de Telescope Coffee, espera un nuevo aumento por parte de su tostador. Su café proviene de Etiopía y Guatemala, ambos ahora afectados por los aranceles. Además, mencionó un alza repentina en el costo de tazas importadas desde China. En sectores como la panadería, productos clave como los huevos también han subido de precio. Prudencio relató que en solo cinco meses, el precio de la caja de huevos pasó de $42 a más de $100. En marzo, una docena alcanzó los $6.22, según el Índice de Precios al Consumidor. Joel Finkelstein, de Qualia Coffee Roasters, advirtió que los nuevos aranceles son solo el último golpe para la industria. Recordó que tras los recortes de USAID bajo la administración Trump, el costo del grano ya había aumentado.

title: “En Guatemala hay un intento de lastimar la gestión del poder público”: Ministro de Finanzas - (Published 15 hour(s), 19 minute(s) ago)
content: El objetivo es crear un millón de empleos hacia 2028, durante los cuatro años de presidencia de Bernardo Arévalo de León, dijo Jonathan Menkos.
resumen:
Jonathan Menkos, ministro de Finanzas de Guatemala, se refirió a la relación con México como sana, de mucha fraternidad y comprensión.
Con el 56 por ciento de sus 18 millones de habitantes bajo la línea de pobreza y el 16 por ciento en pobreza extrema, el gobierno del presidente Bernardo Arévalo está en una carrera contra el tiempo por acortarla mediante un ambicioso plan de inversiones públicas y de expansión económica.
Este considera, por ejemplo, modernizar carreteras vitales para la economía, cobertura eléctrica para 400 mil hogares sin acceso a energía y la descontaminación del Río Motagua, todo lo cual requiere unos 2 mil millones de dólares.
La meta es la creación de un millón de empleos a 2028.
La carga tributaria es apenas de 11,7 por ciento del producto y el presupuesto fiscal representa solo el 15 por ciento.
El ministro guatemalteco de finanzas, Jonathan Menkos, participó en la reunión anual del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) en Santiago.
Se requiere una inversión de unos 2.000 millones de dólares que se deberán ir negociando, aprobando por el Congreso y ejecutando en los próximos cuatro o cinco años.
Guatemala y México son países limítrofes y eso implica un intercambio, una proyección geopolítica, social y económica, significativa.
En la asamblea del BID se ha planteado que la integración regional puede ser parte de la solución a los problemas del desarrollo.
Guatemala exporta y tiene una excelente relación comercial con los Estados Unidos y junto a Centroamérica, son sus espacios de mayor comercio.
El año pasado las remesas debieron cerrar más o menos en 22 mil millones de dólares.
La economía guatemalteca ha crecido en promedio 3.5% y ahora con el plan de expansión fiscal se espera que crezca 4 por ciento.
Guatemala tiene uno de los 10 presupuestos más pequeños del mundo.
El objetivo es que se tiene que elevar la capacidad de crecimiento económico, con una meta de crecimiento del 4,1%.
Se espera crear, a lo largo de los cuatro años del presidente Arévalo, un millón de empleos.
Guatemala tiene una carga tributaria de 11,7%, y el compromiso es elevarla por encima del 12,5%.
La recaudación de este año es récord, se espera que supere el 11,9 del producto.
El presidente Arévalo asumió hace un año y dos meses.
Hay permanentemente un intento de lastimar la gestión del poder público.
Este año se está trabajando con un presupuesto aprobado por 140 de los 160 congresistas.
Se están creando las condiciones para ser un país que al finalizar este gobierno va a estar mejor insertado en la economía global.
Se espera tener grado de inversión y grandes obras de inversión pública.
Se están en los estudios para duplicar el tamaño del Puerto Quetzal.

title: Juan verde, estratega y excargo de los gobiernos de Obama y Biden - (Published 11 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Sostiene que los órdagos de Trump sitúan a Europa ante un «ahora o nunca»y defiende un doble «pacto de Estado» en Madrid y en Bruselas ...
resumen:
Juan Verde, estratega y excargo de los gobiernos de Obama y Biden, afirma: «Llevo 39 años en Estados Unidos y creo por primera vez que una guerra civil es posible». Sostiene que los órdagos de Trump sitúan a Europa ante un «ahora o nunca» y defiende un doble «pacto de Estado» en Madrid y en Bruselas. Juan Verde (Gran Canaria, 1971) trabajó para los Clinton, fue subsecretario adjunto en el Departamento de Comercio bajo mandato de Barack Obama y, en el último cuatrienio, integró el Consejo Asesor de Joe Biden.
Estados Unidos es hoy un país extremadamente polarizado. Deslocalizar la producción industrial a China tuvo un impacto severo en la capacidad económica de la clase media.
Trump no deja de ser una opción populista. Ha creado un culto a la personalidad, es trumpista ante todo. Se enfrentó a 17 candidatos la primera vez y les ganó. Una vez que toma el poder, hace que desaparezca toda oposición. Estamos en un asalto directo a los valores democráticos intentando manipular las instituciones, haciendo lo posible para que el sistema electoral aparezca como no legítimo, tratando de utilizar el FBI, la Policía, los jueces o los medios para concentrar más y más poder.
Trump es una persona narcisista, egocéntrica, que se cree el salvador de la patria y que está por encima intelectualmente de los demás.
Trump se lo está poniendo muy difícil al Partido Demócrata para que pueda ganar unas elecciones de manera justa. Cuestionando la legitimidad del sistema: funciona si yo gano; si no, es porque hay trampa. Y utilizando todas las instituciones a su favor.
Hay casi 300.000 milicias armadas con señores que entrenan los fines de semana porque creen que el sistema está en su contra y que la democracia no es legítima.
El Partido Demócrata perdió su rumbo. Durante décadas tuvo como base a los sindicalistas, a los empleados públicos, a los de las fábricas de la industria, las minorías, los inmigrantes.
Biden sacó a EE UU de la grave crisis de la covid, muy mal gestionada por Trump. Cogimos el país con el mayor déficit y lo dejamos con el mayor superávit. Hicimos la mayor inversión en I+D+I, en educación, en transición ecológica, en investigación contra el cáncer.
Las medidas que está tomando Trump tienen un impacto directo en decenas de miles de personas. No ha habido una sola vez en ningún país del mundo en que los aranceles no hayan tenido un impacto inflacionario.
La UE debe negociar con Estados Unidos, pero desde una posición de igual a igual. Tiene que diversificar sus fuentes, sus mercados, sus aliados. Cualquier negociación con Trump tiene que venir con mecanismos de revisión, de resolución de conflictos.
Necesitamos un pacto de Estado europeo al igual que un pacto de Estado nacional.

title: El mundo se desordena - (Published 21 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: Los ciudadanos de países occidentales despertamos a un mundo que poseía un ordenamiento inédito en la historia de la humanidad. Desde 1945 existen las Naciones Unidas, foro donde los países se reúnen ...
resumen:
Desde 1945 existen las Naciones Unidas. La ONU manda soldados de países miembros para poner orden en Estados en que ha colapsado el sistema político; hoy fuerzas de Kenia están en Haití. Los países europeos desmontaron sus imperios, y las colonias se independizaron, entre ellas Indonesia (1945), India (1947), el Congo exbelga (1960), Argelia (1962) y Angola (1975).

Las potencias acordaron reglas para el comercio internacional, el GATT, que dio origen a la OMC; fundaron el Fondo Monetario Internacional y el Banco Mundial.

La Segunda Guerra Mundial dejó devastadas a las grandes potencias, excepto los EE. UU., que pasó a tener hegemonía. EE. UU. apoyó generosamente la reconstrucción de los países destruidos. La Unión Soviética y los países que ocupó durante la guerra se mantuvieron al margen. Moscú desarrolló armas nucleares, y Washington extendió a sus aliados la protección de su paraguas nuclear.

Los 30 años desde 1945 son el período de mayor crecimiento económico de la historia. Los EE. UU. llevaron la batuta, el comercio internacional se multiplicó y las operaciones se hacían en dólares. Esto se prolongó durante 80 años. Desde la disolución de la Unión Soviética (1991) se sumaron los países excomunistas. En 2001 China se incorporó a la OMC.

Hasta la llegada de Donald Trump, quien piensa que los costos superan a los beneficios, y que se debe retornar al mundo de antes, en que cada país velaba exclusivamente por sus intereses sin consideración a otros y regía la ley del más fuerte.

A sus socios europeos de la OTAN así como a Japón y Corea del Sur, Washington les cierra su paraguas nuclear.

Trump impone en abril 2 aranceles punitivos a todos los países del mundo. El principal blanco es la China, pero también les aplica aranceles punitivos a sus ahora exaliados de la Unión Europea, Gran Bretaña, Japón y Corea del Sur.

Toca a su fin un período de Pax Americana; entramos a otro que se vislumbra más caótico. Las generaciones futuras considerarán al período 1945-2025 como una edad de oro.

title: Juanma Moreno sigue pescando en el centro - (Published 22 hour(s), 50 minute(s) ago)
content: Ni las protestas por la situación de la sanidad pública ni el debate sobre la respuesta a los aranceles mueven a la Junta de su estrategia política ...
resumen:
Juanma Moreno sigue una estrategia política que lo llevó a la mayoría absoluta en Andalucía hace casi tres años.
La llegada de la vicepresidenta del Gobierno a la política andaluza no ha movido al PP ni un centímetro de dicha estrategia.
En la Junta valoran que no ha habido "efecto Montero", más allá de las repercusiones internas de unidad y movilización en el seno de las filas socialistas.
En la Junta aseguran que sus estudios apuntan a que en el PSOE empiezan a ver que recuperar a Montero no fue una buena decisión.
En la Junta sostienen que la vicepresidenta no "tira" y que demoscópicamente el efecto Montero no aparece por ningún lado.
El pasado sábado los sindicatos consiguieron convocar a miles de personas en Sevilla en protesta por la situación de la sanidad pública.
Juanma Moreno dio un pequeño giro en la última sesión de control, refiriéndose a una manifestación legítima que el PSOE y el resto de la izquierda pretendieron politizar.
La consejera de Economía y Hacienda, Carolina España, presentó matices en el interior del Gobierno situando al ministro de Economía, Carlos Cuerpo, en un supuesto sector dialogante y dejando a la titular de Hacienda, María Jesús Montero, enarbolando la bandera de la intransigencia.
Todos los mensajes de la Junta, y en especial de Juanma Moreno, parecen dirigirse hacia el mismo objetivo, consolidar el voto más centrista e históricamente ligado al socialismo andaluz.
Juanma Moreno parece estar en una posición cómoda para alcanzar ese objetivo.

title: La gente dice más barbaridades que nunca - (Published 13 hour(s), 1 minute(s) ago)

title: A Devastating Trade Spat With China Shows Few Signs of Abating - (Published 18 hour(s), 21 minute(s) ago)
content: The Trump administration is in a standoff with the Chinese government as trade tensions escalate, leaving U.S. businesses in the cross hairs ...
resumen:
President Trump’s trade war with China has resulted in tariffs on products exchanged between the countries. There is no end in sight.

The Trump administration has been waiting for Xi Jinping to call Mr. Trump personally.

Businesses that rely on sourcing products from China have been thrown into turmoil.

Mr. Trump has rapidly ratcheted up tariffs on Chinese products, from 54 percent on April 2 to 145 percent just one week later.

The Chinese government raised its tariffs on American goods to 125 percent on Friday.

The administration created a significant carve out to its tariffs on China when it exempted some electronics, including smartphones, laptops and televisions. Those products will still be subject to other tariffs that Mr. Trump has put in place, like a 20 percent fee he added to Chinese goods in response to the country’s role in the fentanyl trade.

Mr. Trump has said he would like to speak with Mr. Xi, but he has stopped short of requesting a phone call.

Trump officials say that dozens of countries have reached out to the administration about negotiations since the levies were imposed. China did not, and instead responded with harsh words and tariffs of its own.

Some officials are concerned that the trade war could soon escalate into a national security crisis, potentially causing the Chinese to move up plans for a military invasion of Taiwan.

The Pentagon is assessing the impact of China potentially cutting off rare earth exports to the United States and possibly blocking certain critical components used in U.S. weapons systems.

Mr. Trump continues to express optimism.

Julian Evans-Pritchard, the head of China economics for the research firm Capital Economics, said the fact that the Chinese authorities had repeatedly matched U.S. tariff hikes suggested that they were in no rush to negotiate.

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, declined to say whether the countries were in communication.

Mr. Trump said that “China wants to make a deal. They just don’t know how quite to go about it.”

Mr. Trump’s moves have taken tariffs to a level far past what would be prohibitive for trade, creating crises for many American businesses that depend on imports from China.

Rick Woldenberg, who runs Learning Resources, said the latest tariffs had already forced him to pause some shipments from China. He called the rates that Mr. Trump had imposed “a joke”.

Learning Resources contracts with factories in Taiwan, India, Vietnam and other countries to make its products, but China is by far its biggest supplier. China accounted for two-thirds of all imports of toys and sporting goods to the United States last year.

Learning Resources employs about 500 people, most of them in the United States. It had planned to hire more this year to keep up with its fast-growing business, but has now abandoned some of those plans.

Mr. Woldenberg said he paid about $2.3 million in tariffs and duties in 2024. This year, he would end up paying more than $100 million if sales somehow kept up with his projections from before the trade war.

Christophe Lavigne, the president of Highfield, which manufactures boats in China and the United States, said he expected to be subject to 198 percent tariffs on some of his imports, and that he has decided to simply stop his shipments for now.

Hobby Lobby, the crafting retailer, told vendors on Thursday that it was delaying shipments from China as a result of the escalating trade war.

The dollar fell to a three-year low on Friday, while Treasury yields continued to swing. A measure of consumer sentiment also tumbled.

Mr. Trump abruptly announced on Wednesday a 90-day pause on the “reciprocal” tariffs that he had unveiled the previous week on countries around the world.

People familiar with the conversations said that members of the White House National Security Council were in touch with counterparts at the Chinese Embassy, and that Cui Tiankai, the former Chinese ambassador, had held meetings in Washington and New York over the past several weeks to discuss the relationship.

In his second term, Mr. Trump has been even more emboldened and unpredictable.

In an annual report released March 31, the Office of the United States Trade Representative detailed the trade barriers that U.S. businesses face when selling abroad, dedicating almost 50 of its nearly 400 pages to China.

China has added some U.S. companies to an unreliable entity list that essentially bars them from doing business in the country. It has also imposed licensing systems to restrict exports of rare earth elements.

On Friday, as it announced its latest increase in tariffs on American products, the Chinese government said it would not raise the rate further because it was already so high that the number no longer made any difference.

China’s Ministry of Commerce said that the United States had used tariffs “for bullying and coercion” and had ultimately become “a laughingstock.”

China also ratcheted up pressure on U.S. companies as it issued new regulations on Friday that will subject semiconductors made by U.S. firms overseas to higher tariffs.

The move will put pressure on companies like Intel, Global Foundries and others that have U.S. chip factories.

title: China Halts Critical Exports as Trade War Intensifies - (Published 15 hour(s), 19 minute(s) ago)
content: Beijing has suspended exports of certain rare earth minerals and magnets that are crucial for the world’s car, semiconductor and aerospace industries.
resumen:
China has suspended exports of a wide range of critical minerals and magnets, threatening to choke off supplies of components central to automakers, aerospace manufacturers, semiconductor companies and military contractors around the world.

Shipments of the magnets have been halted at many Chinese ports while the Chinese government drafts a new regulatory system. Once in place, the new system could permanently prevent supplies from reaching certain companies, including American military contractors.

The official crackdown is part of China’s retaliation for President Trump’s sharp increase in tariffs that started on April 2.

On April 4, the Chinese government ordered restrictions on the export of six heavy rare earth metals, which are refined entirely in China, as well as rare earth magnets, 90 percent of which are produced in China. The metals, and special magnets made with them, can now be shipped out of China only with special export licenses.

Factories in Detroit and elsewhere could be prevented from assembling cars and other products with electric motors that require these magnets.

The so-called heavy rare earth metals covered by the export suspension are used in magnets essential for many kinds of electric motors. These motors are crucial components of electric cars, drones, robots, missiles and spacecraft. Gasoline-powered cars also use electric motors with rare earth magnets for critical tasks like steering.

The metals also go into the chemicals for manufacturing jet engines, lasers, car headlights and certain spark plugs. And these rare metals are vital ingredients in capacitors, which are electrical components of the computer chips that power artificial intelligence servers and smartphones.

Michael Silver, the chairman and chief executive of American Elements, a chemicals supplier based in Los Angeles, said his company had been told it would take 45 days before export licenses could be issued and exports of rare earth metals and magnets would resume.

Daniel Pickard, the chairman of the critical minerals advisory committee for the Office of the United States Trade Representative and Department of Commerce, expressed concern about the availability of rare earths.

China’s Ministry of Commerce, which issued the new export restrictions jointly with the General Administration of Customs, has barred Chinese companies from having any dealings with an ever-lengthening list of American companies, particularly military contractors.

James Litinsky, the executive chairman and chief executive of MP Materials, said that rare earth supplies for military contractors were of particular concern. MP Materials owns the sole rare earths mine in the United States, the Mountain Pass mine in the California desert near the Nevada border, and hopes to start commercial production of magnets in Texas at the end of the year for General Motors and other manufacturers.

One of the metals subject to the new controls, dysprosium oxide, trades for $204 per kilogram in Shanghai, and much more outside China.

China produces 90 percent of the world’s nearly 200,000 tons a year of rare earth magnets, which are far more powerful than conventional iron magnets.

Chinese customs officials are blocking exports of heavy rare earth metals and magnets not just to the United States but to any country, including Japan and Germany.

Until 2023, China produced 99 percent of the world’s supply of heavy rare earth metals.

China also produces 90 percent of the world’s nearly 200,000 tons a year of rare earth magnets.

China’s most famous factory for these magnets is operated by the JL Mag Rare-Earth Company, whose headquarters are in Ganzhou.

The factory supplies the world’s top two electric car producers, Tesla and China’s BYD, with the magnets that power their cars. BYD has said that it buys some of the world’s latest, most powerful magnets from JL Mag, with 15 times the magnetic force per cubic inch of volume as a conventional iron magnet.

Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, made a special inspection visit to JL Mag’s factory in Ganzhou in 2019.

title: Singapore downgrades 2025 GDP growth forecast to 0 to 2%, citing impact of Trump tariffs on global trade - (Published 7 hour(s), 36 minute(s) ago)
content: The tariffs imposed by Trump and the ongoing trade war between the US and China are expected to "weigh significantly on global trade and global economic growth", says the Ministry of Trade and ...
resumen: Singapore has downgraded its gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast for 2025 to 0 per cent to 2 per cent, citing the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs on global trade. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said on Monday (Apr 14). In February, Singapore’s GDP growth forecast for the year remained at 1 per cent to 3 per cent. The US has imposed a baseline tariff of 10 per cent on all countries and higher reciprocal tariffs targeted at countries that run large trade surpluses with the US. The tariffs imposed by Trump and the ongoing trade war between the US and China are expected to "weigh significantly on global trade and global economic growth". The growth outlook of economies in the region will be "negatively affected" by a fall in external demand partly due to the tariffs’ wider impact on global trade and growth. Singapore's economy grew 3.8 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 compared with the same period a year ago. On a quarter-on-quarter seasonally adjusted basis, the economy contracted by 0.8 per cent compared to the 0.5 per cent growth in the fourth quarter of 2024. The tariffs, announced by Trump on Apr 2, impose a universal 10 per cent tariff on all imports into the country, with higher rates for countries deemed to have treated the US "unfairly". Singapore, which currently imposes zero tariffs on US imports, is still subject to the baseline 10 per cent rate. The tariff war between the US and China has also intensified, with China raising duties on US goods to 125 per cent. The growth outlook of the US has deteriorated as rising import costs are likely to weaken consumption. China’s growth outlook has also softened as its exports growth is expected to stall amidst the trade war with the US. Product-specific tariffs, such as those on cars and automotive parts coming into the US, also remain in place. Trump's commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, on Sunday said that critical technology products from China would face separate new duties along with semiconductors within the next two months. MTI noted the "substantial" downside risks, such as a possible drop in consumer spending, increased costs and global supply chain disruption. The manufacturing sector, wholesale trade sector, and transportation and storage sector in particular set to be hit by weaker global demand. The finance and insurance sector could also see weaker trading activity. The uncertain economic backdrop will likely dampen capital investment spending and constrain credit intermediation activity. The growth of payments firms could moderate in tandem with tepid business activity and lower consumer spending. MTI will continue to closely monitor global and domestic developments, and make further adjustments to the forecast if needed. The ministry will also release its preliminary GDP estimates for the first quarter of 2025 in May. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said on Apr 8 that the economy will be significantly impacted. Singapore will form a national task force to support businesses and workers in response to the tariffs. The task force, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong, will include representatives from Singapore's economic agencies, the Singapore Business Federation, the Singapore National Employers Federation and the National Trades Union Congress.

title: Trump tariffs live updates: Trump will explain tariffs on electronics on Monday - (Published 11 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: In a dramatic move Wednesday, Trump authorized a 90-day pause in the higher tariffs for most countries he announced last week while maintaining a 10% universal tariff.
resumen:
President Donald Trump said on Sunday there will be no exceptions for tariffs on electronics and that he would clarify his administration's policy on Monday.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection announced late Friday that some smartphones, computers, chips and other electronics would be exempted from tariffs.

Trump posted Sunday afternoon, that tariffs on these products are “just moving to a different Tariff ‘bucket.’”

Trump said, “There was no Tariff ‘exemption’ announced on Friday" and that semiconductor tariffs will “just be moving to a different Tariff ‘bucket.’”

Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: “NOBODY is getting ‘off the hook’ for the unfair Trade Balances, and Non Monetary Tariff Barriers, that other Countries have used against us, especially not China which, by far, treats us the worst!”

Trump’s top economic and trade aides made the same argument on Sunday talk shows: that smartphones, computers and other electronics were removed from the sweeping reciprocal tariffs the president announced on April 2 and will be part of a separate national security classification under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 Trump is to announce, they said.

“We are taking a look at Semiconductors and the WHOLE ELECTRONICS SUPPLY CHAIN in the upcoming National Security Tariff Investigations,” Trump wrote.

A bulletin posted by U.S. Customs and Border Protection late Friday night said the administration was exempting smartphones, computers, and other electronics from his reciprocal tariffs.

Trump said, "We’ll be very specific on Monday. We're taking in a lot of money. As a country, we’re taking in a lot of money."

The Trump administration announced that smartphones, computers, chips and other electronics would be exempt from the escalating tariffs Trump has imposed on other Chinese imports, which now stand at 145%.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement to ABC News: "President Trump has made it clear America cannot rely on China to manufacture critical technologies such as semiconductors, chips, smartphones, and laptops."

A White House official told ABC News that the president has said autos, steel, pharmaceuticals, chips and other specific materials will be included in specific tariffs.

The administration had earlier imposed 20% fentanyl-related tariffs in February.

title: Apple, Intel y otros aliviados: Trump deja fuera de aranceles 'recíprocos' al sector tecnológico - (Published 20 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: El gobierno de Trump ha decidido dejar libre a smartphones, computadoras y otros dispositivos tecnológicos de los llamados 'aranceles recíprocos', incluyendo a los impuestos a China.
resumen: El gobierno de Trump ha decidido dejar libre a smartphones, computadoras y otros dispositivos tecnológicos de los llamados 'aranceles recíprocos', incluyendo a los impuestos a China. La medida se produce tras la decisión del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles mínimos del 145 % a las importaciones procedentes de China. Esta acción impacta directamente a grandes empresas tecnológicas estadounidenses, como Apple. Trump justifica estos aranceles señalando la participación de China en las cadenas de suministro de fentanilo, una sustancia responsable de cientos de miles de muertes en Estados Unidos en los últimos veinte años. La Oficina de Aduanas y Protección Fronteriza de los Estados Unidos (CPB por sus siglas en inglés) esta medida se aplicará a los productos importados o salieran de la nación norteamericana desde el 5 de abril. Los semiconductores también están excluidos de un arancel "base" del 10 % para la mayoría de los socios comerciales. Las exclusiones contemplan productos como teléfonos inteligentes, laptops, discos duros, procesadores, chips de memoria y pantallas planas, todos ellos artículos electrónicos de consumo masivo que, en su mayoría, no se fabrican en Estados Unidos. La Casa Blanca emitió un memorando en el que señala que las exenciones también abarcan los ajustes arancelarios relacionados con el envío de paquetes pequeños. Previamente, el expresidente Donald Trump había iniciado acciones para eliminar la llamada exención "de minimis", comenzando por China. Esta exención permite que los envíos con un valor igual o inferior a 800 dólares ingresen a Estados Unidos sin pagar aranceles. “El presidente Trump ha dejado claro que Estados Unidos no puede depender de China para la fabricación de tecnologías críticas como semiconductores, chips, teléfonos inteligentes y computadoras portátiles”, afirmó la secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, en un comunicado. Leavitt también señaló que “estas empresas se están apresurando a trasladar su producción a Estados Unidos”.

title: Mercosur apuesta por flexibilidad arancelaria frente a guerra comercial - (Published 12 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Planes ante la incertidumbre internacional tras los aranceles anunciados el pasado 2 de abril por el presidente Trump Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron este viernes en Buenos Aires y acordaron ...
resumen:
Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron el 13 de abril de 2025 en Buenos Aires y acordaron ampliar las listas de excepciones al arancel externo común como principal respuesta regional a la guerra comercial global, tras los aranceles anunciados el 2 de abril por el presidente Trump.

En la reunión participaron los cancilleres de Argentina, Gerardo Werthein; Brasil, Mauro Vieira; Uruguay, Mario Lubetkin; Paraguay, Rubén Ramírez, y Bolivia (país en proceso de adhesión como miembro pleno del Mercosur), Celinda Sosa Lunda.

Los ministros coincidieron en la importancia de hacer frente a los desafíos que presenta el actual contexto internacional de la guerra comercial global y, en ese marco, coincidieron en la necesidad de ampliar temporariamente la Lista Nacional de Excepciones al Arancel Externo Común de cada Estado parte.

El comercio del bloque fundado en 1991 por Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay se rige por un arancel externo común (AEC), con alícuotas que van desde el 0 al 35 %, pero cada miembro del Mercosur cuenta con una Lista Nacional de Excepciones (LNE) al AEC en una cantidad limitada de productos que puede cambiar cada seis meses, previa notificación a sus socios.

Actualmente, Argentina y Brasil pueden incorporar hasta 100 códigos en sus respectivas LNE, mientras que Uruguay puede tener en su lista hasta 225 productos y Paraguay, 649.

El número total de productos de cada LNE se podrá incrementar ahora en hasta 50 códigos arancelarios en los que se podrán subir las alícuotas más allá del AEC.

Según el comunicado oficial, los ministros subrayaron avances recientes como la suscripción de un acuerdo con Singapur y la conclusión de las negociaciones con la Unión Europea, y manifestaron su compromiso en avanzar prioritariamente con las negociaciones con la Asociación Europea de Libre Comercio (EFTA, por sus siglas en inglés) y con Emiratos Árabes Unidos, con vistas a concluir ambas negociaciones durante el presente semestre.

El ministro de Exteriores de Brasil, Mauro Vieira, dijo que la reunión había sido “muy buena” y se llevó a cabo en un “clima de amistad y comprensión”.

El canciller brasileño destacó que el encuentro fue clave para analizar las medidas a tomar “para hacer que el Mercosur sea más fuerte, más activo y tenga mejores resultados en este momento de gran inestabilidad en el mundo”.

El ministro de Relaciones Exteriores uruguayo, Mario Lubetkin, mencionó que el Mercosur se enfrenta a una disyuntiva entre reforzarse o debilitarse y celebró que se encamine hacia un “refuerzo importante”.

Además, describió la reunión como “positiva” y señaló: “En algunos ambientes había un escenario de tensión y la verdad fue una reunión muy franca, fuerte como tienen que ser las reuniones francas”.

title: Where Trump’s deportations are sending migrants - (Published 14 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: In the first few months of his second term, President Donald Trump has taken steps to carry out what he has previously said will be “the largest domestic deportation operation” in U.S. history.
resumen:
In the first few months of his second term, President Donald Trump has taken steps to carry out what he has previously said will be “the largest domestic deportation operation” in U.S. history. The administration says its moves — which include hundreds of deportation flights and Trump’s invocation of the seldom-used 1798 Alien Enemies Act — are necessary to stem unauthorized immigration to the United States. Experts say recipient countries are likely feeling economic and political pressure from the United States to accept deportees.

Since Trump took office, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has deported non-U.S. citizens via charter and commercial flights, although the exact number of migrants is unclear. According to data from Witness at the Border, a U.S.-based migrant advocacy group, there have been more than 350 deportation flights since the start of the year. Some of them were military aircraft, which defense officials stopped using to transfer migrants in early March because it was expensive and inefficient, the Wall Street Journal reported. According to ICE, the average per-hour cost of a regular charter flight is $8,577 and can be as high as nearly $27,000 for a “special high-risk” charter flight, depending on aircraft requirements.

The most notable deportations occurred on March 15, when Trump invoked the 1798 Alien Enemies Act to deport to El Salvador more than two hundred alleged members of the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang, which the United States has designated a terrorist organization. (The U.S. government has reportedly provided little evidence of their alleged membership.) A federal judge temporarily blocked the move, and the case eventually came before the Supreme Court, which overturned the decision, allowing the Trump administration to continue deportations.

The deportations are part of Trump’s promise to crack down on unauthorized immigration to the United States. Tom Homan, Trump’s “border czar” and former acting director of ICE (2017–2018), said the administration’s deportation policy prioritizes the removal of individuals with criminal records and those who are suspected national security threats.

According to federal data, while border crossings have plummeted, the Trump administration deported fewer people in February 2025 than the Joe Biden administration did in February the previous year. Biden deported approximately four million people during his presidency compared to the roughly three million deported by his predecessor, Barack Obama.

Many migrants are being sent to third countries rather than their countries of origin. Central America’s so-called Northern Triangle countries of El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras made up more than half of all deportations in March. Most other destinations were countries in Latin America and the Caribbean, including Colombia, Jamaica, and Mexico.

The Trump administration has reached agreements with several Latin American nations for them to serve as stopover locations or destinations for deported migrants. During February visits, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio struck deals with El Salvador and Guatemala, both of which agreed to accept deportation flights of their own citizens in addition to other nationalities. Brazil, China, Colombia, Costa Rica, Honduras, India, Mexico, Panama, and Venezuela have also agreed to receive or have already received U.S. deportation flights.

Meanwhile, a few hundred migrants — most Venezuelan — have cycled through the U.S. naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. In late March, the Trump administration sent a new group of migrants to the base to await deportation.

Some countries, including Colombia and Panama, have said they are providing migrants with food, water, and medical care, as well as the chance to apply for asylum with assistance from UN agencies. But concerns remain from human rights groups about how migrants are treated upon their arrival in other countries, such as El Salvador, where deportees have been transferred to the country’s notorious mega prison.

The Trump administration is also reportedly seeking agreements with several other countries, including those in Africa, Asia, and Europe.

Some recipient countries have likely agreed to take U.S. deportees because they are facing economic and political pressure from the Trump administration. In late January, Colombia blocked two military aircraft carrying U.S. deportees from landing in the country but later walked back its deportation ban after Trump threatened steep retaliatory tariffs on Colombian imports.

Domestically, the Trump administration’s deportation agenda has faced pushback. Legal experts say the White House’s policies lack transparency and they have questioned the administration’s authority to deport migrants without due process, while several rights groups have filed lawsuits. In April, the Trump administration said in a legal filing that it made an “administrative error” in transferring a Maryland man to prison in his home country of El Salvador the month prior, but that it could not ensure his return given he is no longer in U.S. custody.

title: Polls close in Ecuador's razor-tight presidential runoff - (Published 11 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Polls closed in Ecuador's too-close-to-call presidential election Sunday, with incumbent Daniel Noboa hoping to fend off a charismatic leftist challenger after a campaign dominated by drug-related ...
resumen: Incumbent President Daniel Noboa claimed a runaway victory in Ecuador's presidential election on Sunday. With over 90 percent of the votes counted, the National Election Council said Noboa had a 12-point lead over his leftist rival Luisa Gonzalez. Official results showed Noboa with 56 percent of the vote, against Gonzalez's 44 percent. Speaking to supporters, the 37-year-old president claimed a "historic victory". Gonzalez questioned the results, accusing Noboa of "the most grotesque electoral fraud" and called for a recount of the ballots. The campaign was dominated by worries about the economy and cartel violence. Noboa has staked his political fortunes on tough security policies. He has deployed the military to the streets, captured drug capos and invited the United States to send special forces. On the eve of the ballot, Noboa declared a 60-day state of emergency in the capital Quito and several provinces. The nation averaged a killing every hour at the start of the year. Rampant bloodshed has fueled economic malaise and swelled the ranks of Ecuador's poor to 28 percent of the population. About 13.7 million Ecuadorans were obliged to vote. Noboa's win is likely to see him double down on hardline security policies. Analysts said that Gonzalez's close ties to ex-president Rafael Correa may have hurt her at the polls.

resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro de EEUU, Scott Bessent, llegará a Buenos Aires el día siguiente al anuncio del acuerdo con el FMI y el primer día sin cepo cambiario. La visita durará unas 12 horas y no es una gira por la región. Bessent viajará solamente al país y luego regresará a Washington.

Bessent podría llegar con Robert Citrone, inversor y fundador del Grupo Discovery; Matt del Orfano, experto en economía argentina; Matt Schlapp, presidente de CPAC y cercano a Trump; y Soledad Cedro, CEO de CPAC Argentina.

La visita configura un claro respaldo a la gestión de Milei. La agenda formal incluye un encuentro con Milei y Luis Caputo, un almuerzo con empresarios y CEO de multinacionales y otros encuentros con el equipo económico.

La llegada de Bessent podría incluir un refuerzo de financiamiento para Argentina a través de una línea de crédito especial. EEUU podría analizar un préstamo para que el país cancele el swap con China. El swap de monedas vigente entre el BCRA y el Banco Popular chino es por casi USD 18.000 millones.

También se habló de firmar un acuerdo de provisión de minerales críticos, como el litio, y "tierras raras".

Otra versión indica que el funcionario de Trump podría llegar con un acuerdo de “arancel cero” para un grupo de productos. Las patentes de los laboratorios, las trabas para importar y las falsificaciones de primeras marcas americanas son el eje de las exigencias de EEUU a la hora de negociar cuestiones arancelarias.

Bessent tiene buena relación con José Luis Daza y con Pierpaolo Barbieri, fundador de Ualá.

title: Incertidumbre por las reacciones que pueden generar los anuncios de MIlei - (Published 19 hour(s), 33 minute(s) ago)
content: La ciudadanía se encuentra hoy atravesando horas intranquilas debido a la espera de las repercusiones económicas que traerán aparejados los anuncios emitidos desde la administración nacional.
resumen:
La ciudadanía espera con incertidumbre lo que pueda ocurrir tras los anuncios del Gobierno nacional.

Horas intranquilas debido a la espera de las repercusiones económicas que traerán los anuncios emitidos el viernes pasado desde la administración nacional.

El conjunto de ciudadanos argentinos se encuentran hoy atravesando horas intranquilas debido a la espera para comenzar a ver las inmediatas repercusiones, en la economía cotidiana, que traerán aparejados los anuncios económicos emitidos -entre los días jueves y viernes pasados- desde la administración nacional.

Con la devaluación del 30% -del peso en reacción al dólar- mañana darán inicio una serie de cambios en la economía argentina en todos los niveles.

Dichos cambios favorecerán a los intereses geopolíticos y económicos de los EE.UU. y en Argentina a algunos sectores poderosos y perjudicarán a la totalidad de los sectores menos favorecidos económicamente de nuestro país.

Algunas de las trágicas consecuencias –inevitables- que se saben devendrán de las medidas económicas anunciadas son: un fuerte incremento de la inflación, una sobre estimulada voracidad (en los individuos y en las empresas) por hacerse de dólares –a como dé lugar-, un incremento directo e inmediato de las tarifas (porque están dolarizadas por contrato), y una profunda acentuación de la recesión en curso.

La puesta en marcha de la maquinaria económica (llamada PLAN) concebida por el FMI -y aplicada por Milei, Caputo y sus funcionarios próximos- demanda lo mínimo no negociable.

La ciudadanía solamente espera -asomada y expectante- mirando los densos nubarrones que se ciernen en el horizonte.

Cada argentino de a pie solo podrá comprar oficialmente 100 dólares por mes.

El Banco Central le vendió a precio “viejo” casi 400 millones de dólares a algunos afortunados.

La medida de fuerza asumida por la CGT el día 10 de abril contó con la intromisión de los mecanismos de propaganda propios de los regímenes más autoritarios de la historia de la edad moderna.

En las centrales de transporte –y en diversos centros de concentración de ciudadanía en tránsito- de CABA altoparlantes emitían mensajes del gobierno boicoteando al paro -en los cuales se nombraba a los dirigentes sindicales como “casta”- e instando a la población a realizar denuncias.

La administración nacional decidió sobre el cierre de la misma acometer contra el ciudadano español -consultor y asesor de imagen- Gutiérrez Rubí expulsándolo del país por… trabajar para la campaña electoral de Jorge Macri.

Trump suspendió los aranceles punitorios por 90 días.

Trump logró sostener la cuota mínima arancelaria del 10% para todos los países del mundo -excepto China a la que le clavó 165%-.

Argentina no obtuvo ningún beneficio y fue advertida que EE.UU. cesaría la compra de carne de nuestro país para dar prioridad a los productores estadounidenses.

El diputado paraguayo Rubén Rubín dijo: Cómo será de exitosa la economía de Paraguay que los paraguayos prefieren vivir en Argentina con hiperinflación que en nuestro país con superávit.

content: La guerra de aranceles que inició Estados Unidos generó una fuerte volatilidad en la divisa en el país y la mantiene por encima de los $4.000. Expertos proyectan que podría seguir con un notable forta ...
resumen: El dólar en Colombia cerró el 11 de abril en promedio de $4.338,47. La guerra comercial iniciada por Estados Unidos al imponer aranceles a sus socios comerciales (incluida Colombia, con una base del 10%) causó la volatilidad del dólar. El director de Economía y Gobierno de la Universidad EAN, Juan Carlos Rivera, confirmó que el dólar mostró una tendencia alcista, alcanzando niveles cercanos a los $4.400, debido a la incertidumbre económica global y las expectativas de una posible recesión en Estados Unidos. La subida del dólar afecta el costo de los productos importados, lo que puede incrementar los precios de la canasta básica y otros bienes de consumo. Para Semana Santa y el resto de abril, se espera que el dólar continúe la tendencia alcista, con proyecciones de alcanzar niveles entre $4.500 y $4.800. Al cierre del 13 de abril, el precio promedio de compra de dólar en las casas de cambio de Colombia fue de $4.046,00, mientras que el de venta se ubicó en $4.215,00. Expertos de Visión Davivienda consideran que el dólar global (DXY) se mantendrá cerca de 100 puntos. La tasa de cambio promedio del mes se mantendría sobre $4.300, con un rango de movimiento entre $4.280 y $4.420.

title: China y EEUU, ¿duelo por aranceles… o por la hegemonía? - (Published 20 hour(s), 23 minute(s) ago)
content: Qué busca Donald Trump con los aranceles a China. El detrás de la guerra comercial. Qué pasa con América Latina.
resumen:
El 13 de abril de 2025, Estados Unidos quedó frente a frente con China. Una semana después de imponer “aranceles recíprocos” a los productos de 180 países, el mandatario estadounidense dio marcha atrás y el único país castigado terminó siendo China con un impuesto de 125% a sus mercaderías.

Trump retomó la iniciativa del comercio global y busca reestructurarlo; impidió respuestas de los grupos integrados como BRICS o Mercosur obligando a los países a actuar, uno a uno, desde posiciones más debilitadas y quedó en un duelo frente a frente con la principal rival de EEUU: China.

El economista Gustavo Girado, director del posgrado sobre China contemporánea de la Universidad Nacional de Lanús, analizó que la disputa no es solo económica sino por la hegemonía.

La empresa Apple transportó de urgencia 600 toneladas de iPhones desde la India a EEUU y otro cargamento similar desde China para eludir los aranceles.

La especialista en Asuntos Asiáticos del CARI, Lía Rodriguez de la Vega, explicó que los sectores más afectados en India serían: a) los productos farmacéuticos; b) los textiles y las prendas de vestir; c) los productos agrícolas; d) los automóviles y sus componentes y e) los componentes informáticos y electrónicos.

En 2023, EEUU e India lanzaron una Iniciativa sobre Tecnologías Críticas y Emergentes, para profundizar la cooperación en IA, tecnología cuántica, ciberespacio, 6G, biotecnología, semiconductores, defensa y espacio.

El gobierno del primer ministro Narendra Modi se reunió en febrero con Trump en la Casa Blanca y está trabajando en un acuerdo bilateral de comercio.

El presidente Lula da Silva dijo que Brasil está llevando a cabo una estrategia en al menos dos frentes: negociar con Washington la tarifa del 10%, y mantener contactos políticos y diplomáticos con países de América Latina y, en particular, con China.

En la IX cumbre de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC), se dio una declaración conjunta de repudio a las medidas económicas y antimigrantes de Trump, apoyada por 31 de los 33 mandatarios de la CELAC, con Argentina y Paraguay rechazándola.

Se dio un encuentro bilateral, al margen de la cumbre, de Lula y la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum.

title: Milei, Trump, el FMI y la sombra de la dolarización - (Published 20 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: La “tercera fase del programa económico” de Javier Milei y Luis Caputo es, en realidad, la primera fase del programa económico dictado desde Washington para el gobierno argentino. El dólar no se cayó ...
resumen: El nuevo acuerdo con el FMI marca el inicio del programa económico exigido por Estados Unidos: una devaluación cercana al 30%, el fin de los subsidios, privatizaciones, reformas estructurales y un giro geopolítico contra China. Tras dos meses de resistencia, Milei y Caputo cedieron y aceleraron las medidas. El Tesoro norteamericano ya pisa Buenos Aires para garantizar el cumplimiento. Washington pide más que ajuste: quiere influir en el gabinete, quedarse con recursos estratégicos y allanar el camino a una eventual dolarización. La “tercera fase del programa económico” de Javier Milei y Luis Caputo es, en realidad, la primera fase del programa económico dictado desde Washington para el gobierno argentino. El dólar sufrirá una nueva devaluación, cercana al 30 por ciento. La visita del secretario del Tesoro norteamericano, Scott Bessent, solo puede explicarse si viene a controlar su aplicación. Entre las condiciones que se conocieron hay reformas estructurales regresivas y el fin de los subsidios a la energía. La salida del cepo responde a una exigencia de Estados Unidos y a la necesidad de tapar con algo que parezca una buena noticia el dato de inflación de marzo. Este mismo acuerdo con el Fondo estaba sobre la mesa desde comienzos de febrero, pero se demoró dos meses por la resistencia de Milei y Caputo a devaluar y sacar el cepo. Durante esos dos meses las reservas del Banco Central cayeron 5 mil millones de dólares. El 4 de abril el presidente y el ministro de Economía aterrizaron en Buenos Aires. El 8 de abril se publicó el Acuerdo Técnico. El 12 de abril el directorio del FMI aprobó el nuevo programa. Esto no habría sido posible sin el apoyo de la Casa Blanca, que se encargó de hacer saber que supervisa de cerca las negociaciones a través de Mauricio Claver Carone. Para contar con Trump, Milei debe alejarse de China. El Banco Central emitió un comunicado que informaba que la renovación del total del tramo activado del swap, que consiste en 5 mil millones de dólares. La ‘renovación’ que anunció el Banco Central no es otra cosa que una nueva extensión de ese plazo, que patea hasta el año que viene la devolución del crédito ejecutado por Massa en 2023. No implica fondos frescos para la Argentina ni significa un desplante para Estados Unidos. En 2026 se acaba el swap. La Casa Blanca espera que el gobierno argentino rompa lazos con China, salga del Mercosur y le dé a empresas norteamericanas acceso preferencial a los recursos estratégicos, además de reformas estructurales, privatizaciones e influencia en el nombramiento de posiciones clave del gabinete a cambio de un apoyo que va más allá del acuerdo con el Fondo Monetario Internacional. Milei viajó a Paraguay a ver a su par Santiago Peña. Juntos boicotearon a pedido de Estados Unidos la declaración de consenso de la CELAC. Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron en Buenos Aires. El gobierno se compromete a modificar el esquema de jubilaciones durante el año 2026 y también a hacer modificaciones en la normativa en materia laboral y fiscal, incluyendo una baja de retenciones y eliminación del monotributo. También se dará de baja la segmentación tarifaria en materia energética, terminando con los subsidios en ese área. Por una resolución de la IGJ Milei convirtió en sociedades anónimas Fabricaciones Militares, Télam, la Administración General de Puerto y otras empresas públicas. Se publicó un decreto que pone en marcha el proceso de venta de las centrales hidroeléctricas de Alicurá, El Chocón, Cerros Colorados y Piedra del Aguila. Los cambios en el gabinete parecen inminentes. El candidato para reemplazar a los tres es Federico Sturzenegger. Esta semana pasó por la Argentina una comitiva de quince empresarios norteamericanos. Se dividen en dos grupos: los que vienen a vender cosas, representantes de empresas de seguridad, salud y telecomunicaciones, y los que vienen a llevarse cosas, de los rubros de energía y minería. Estuvo en el país esta semana Ashok Pinto, funcionario del Departamento de Comercio para Mercados Globales. Visitó las instalaciones de Exolgan y tuvo encuentros cara a cara con los secretarios de Minería, Luis Lucero, y Energía, María Tettamantti del gobierno nacional. En ambos encuentros estuvo acompañada por la encargada de Negocios de la Embajada, Abigail Dressel. En poco más de dos meses Dressel ya tuvo reuniones con todos los gobernadores patagónicos: Ignacio Torres (Chubut) el 5 de febrero, Claudio Vidal (Santa Cruz) el 7 de febrero, Alberto Weretilneck (Río Negro) el 18 de febrero, Gustavo Melella (Tierra del Fuego) el 5 de marzo y Rolando Figueroa (Neuquén) el 3 de abril. Visitó Ushuaia y Vaca Muerta, además de IMPSA. En el paquete que se estaba diseñando entre los dos países estaba incluída una ayuda financiera que permitiría la dolarización de la economía argentina.

title: Global trade dynamics amidst US–China tariff war - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: The bilateral trade in goods between the US and China faces the risk of being severed due to the imposition of steep tariffs ...
resumen:
In 2024, Chinese imports from the US accounted for 5.5 percent of their total imports. If this share decreases in proportion to the decline projected in the US, it could drop to 1.5 percent, thereby generating $105 billion in export opportunities for other countries to China. US exports to China encompass a wide range of products, including electronics, machinery, nuclear reactors, agricultural goods, oil, vehicles, plastics, pharmaceutical products, perfumes, toiletries, and cosmetics.

The impact of Trump's Reciprocal Tariff (TRT) remains uncertain, but it has divided the world into three distinct blocs: the US, China, and the rest of the world (ROW). The US and China are locked in a tariff war.

The bilateral trade in goods between the US and China faces the risk of being severed due to the imposition of steep tariffs: a combined 125 percent plus 20 percent by the US against China, and a retaliatory 125 percent by China effective April 12, alongside the 15 percent tariff it enacted on March 10, 2025. Exports from alternative sources in the ROW are subject to a 10 percent TRT, but China imposes no equivalent tariff on them.

The 10 percent TRT on countries outside the US and China is set to remain in effect for at least 90 days following the pause on April 10, 2025.

In 2024, merchandise trade between the US and China totaled $583 billion, with $144 billion in US exports to China and $439 billion in imports from China to the US. China's share in US imports is forecasted to decrease from 14 percent to 4 percent (The Budget Lab, April 10, 2025), potentially creating approximately $167 billion in export opportunities for other nations to the US. China's exports to the US are predominantly machinery, electronics, and telecommunications equipment.

In 2024, Chinese imports from the US accounted for 5.5 percent of their total imports. If this share decreases in proportion to the decline projected in the US, it could drop to 1.5 percent, thereby generating $105 billion in export opportunities for other countries to China. US exports to China encompass a wide range of products, including electronics, machinery, nuclear reactors, agricultural goods, oil, vehicles, plastics, pharmaceutical products, perfumes, toiletries, and cosmetics.

The above estimates are partially invalidated by the exemption from TRT granted to smartphones, semiconductors, chips, laptops, computer monitors and various electronic parts.

Under the TRT regime, the US and China will seek identical goods or close substitutes from third countries to replace trade that previously occurred directly between them. Both countries will face elevated costs compared to pre-TRT levels. Trade with third countries will arise whenever the tariff-inclusive price from those nations is lower than the tariff-inclusive price of similar goods from China.

The wide gap between the US tariffs—10 percent TRT plus pre-exiting tariffs on most countries (total 25 percent in case of Bangladesh for instance) and 145 percent on Chinese goods except high tech items—makes other countries particularly appealing during the current TRT regime.

Markets are quick to capitalise on ripe opportunities, often finding ways to navigate enduring trade barriers and exploit newly emerged arbitrage prospects. This can involve malpractices like transshipment—routing goods through third countries—or strategies such as resourcing and relocating operations to leverage tariff disparities. Consequently, fresh trade and investment opportunities will arise in sectors like textiles, footwear, machinery, and other categories within the broader US–China trade spectrum.

US garment and footwear importers can establish partnerships with companies in alternative locations, driving expansion in global production for these industries. US companies catering to Chinese consumers and producers often maintain production capacities outside the US—for instance, car manufacturing facilities in Mexico. Such companies can adopt similar redirection strategies, leading to increased production of goods that China imports from other parts of the world outside the US.

The ongoing trade war between the US and China may inadvertently offer a modest boost to growth in the ROW, even as it dampens real GDP growth in both the US and China. Over the long term, not accounting for the latest exemptions, their economies were projected to shrink by 0.6 percent each, while the ROW could see a slight 0.07 percent increase in growth (The Budget Lab, ibid).

Bangladesh, in particular, stands to benefit significantly, as US consumers face price hikes of 64 percent for apparel and 44 percent for textiles (The Budget Lab, ibid), prompting a shift toward more affordable alternatives. Bangladesh, being a leading low-cost supplier, is well-positioned to capitalise on this shift.

The outcomes of ROW negotiations with the US over the next 90 days will be closely monitored by the Chinese government and global businesses. The current high tariff levels are challenging to maintain, given the significant dispersion between the three blocs. The pause in tariff escalation reflects a retreat by White House influencers who oppose using the TRT as a negotiating tool rather than a means of revenue generation or manufacturing rehabilitation in the US.

title: How Brexit, a Startling Act of Economic Self-Harm, Foreshadowed Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 16 hour(s), 4 minute(s) ago)
content: Britain’s decision to leave the European Union in 2016 was sold to voters as a magic bullet that would revitalize the country’s economy. Its impact is still reverberating.
resumen:
Britain has watched President Trump’s tariffs with a mix of shock, fascination and queasy recognition. The country embarked on a similar experiment in economic isolationism when it voted to leave the European Union in 2016. Nearly nine years after the Brexit referendum, it is still reckoning with the costs.

Critics once described Brexit as the greatest act of economic self-harm by a Western country in the post-World War II era.

Mr. Trump uses a similar playbook to erect walls around the United States.

Mr. Trump’s abrupt reversal last week of some of his tariffs, in the face of a bond-market revolt, recalled Britain, where Liz Truss, a short-lived prime minister, was forced to retreat from radical tax cuts that frightened the markets. Her misbegotten experiment was the culmination of a cycle of extreme policies set off by Britain’s decision to forsake the world’s largest trading bloc.

Mark Malloch Brown, a British diplomat who served as deputy secretary general of the United Nations, said that Britain now faces a hard choice between rebuilding trade ties with Europe or preserving them with Mr. Trump’s America.

The government’s Office of Budget Responsibility estimates that Britain’s overall trade volume is about 15 percent lower than it would have been had it remained in the European Union. Long-term productivity is 4 percent lower than it would have been because of trade barriers with Europe.

By the middle of 2022, investment in Britain was 11 percent below what it would have been without Brexit, based on a model by John Springford. Trade in goods was 7 percent lower and gross domestic product 5.5 percent lower, according to Mr. Springford, a fellow at the Center for European Reform, a think tank in London.

Mr. Trump has kicked off even more volatility by imposing, redoubling and then pausing various tariffs. His actions affect dozens of countries, most drastically the United States and China.

Ms. Truss’s plan for debt-funded tax cuts triggered a sell-off of British government bonds.

A similar sell-off of American bonds began last week, with far-reaching implications for the United States.

In Britain’s case, fears of a credit crisis forced Ms. Truss to shelve the tax cuts, and she soon lost her job.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer last week ruled out relaxing the government’s self-imposed fiscal constraints, citing the blowback to Ms. Truss’s free-market experiment.

Richard Portes, a professor of economics at London Business School, said that confidence has been shaken, and people are now much more sensitive to policy inconsistency and policy irresponsibility.

Brexit also diminished Britain’s influence on the diplomatic stage, something it has only recently begun to recoup with Mr. Starmer’s efforts to act as a bridge between Europe and the United States.

A defense pact with the European Union is being held up by France’s demand that Britain make concessions on fishing rights.

The years of bitter debate divided and radicalized the Conservative Party, which governed from 2010 to 2024.

Tony Travers, a professor of politics at the London School of Economics, said that Brexit did not correct any of the problems caused by deindustrialization.

Frustrations over the economy and immigration were among the reasons that voters swept out the Conservatives in favor of Mr. Starmer’s Labour Party last year.

Mr. Trump’s MAGA coalition has some of the same ideological fault lines as the Brexiteers, pitting economic nationalists like Stephen K. Bannon against globalists like Elon Musk.

Professor Travers said that Brexit caused profound damage to the Conservative Party.

title: Trump didn’t cave on tariffs. He wants us to slowly boil like frogs in a pot | Friendly Fire - (Published 17 hour(s), 49 minute(s) ago)
content: He began the socialization of his terrible economic policy – and the media predictably fell for it. Trump treats us like boiling frogs swimming in a pot of tepid water with the heat turned on, until ...
resumen:
Julie Roginsky and Mike DuHaime discuss political events.

Julie: Trump did not cave on tariffs. He began the socialization of his terrible economic policy. Trump treats us like boiling frogs swimming in a pot of tepid water with the heat turned on, until they are slowly boiled to death without even realizing it. The bulk of his awful plan is still in place. He kept exorbitantly high tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China, our three largest trading partners. The 25% tariffs he had levied earlier on steel, cars and auto parts continue to be in effect. Trump also instituted a universal 10% tariff on every other country. On Wednesday, he pledged to impose new tariffs on pharmaceuticals. He will slowly raise tariffs on individual countries that don’t give him a vig or otherwise enrich him. The American consumer is in for a world of hurt.

Mike: Trump is trying to fundamentally alter two things. First, he wants to remake how the government collects revenue. Secondly, Trump truly believes we can bring back more manufacturing to this country. Tariffs on China and Vietnam are not bringing back high-paying, high-tech manufacturing jobs. They are bringing back making T-shirts and sneakers, which are low-wage jobs.

Q: A trade war with China will disrupt daily life for Americans. New Jersey relies on Chinese imports the most: electronics, clothing, tools, toys, so many other things.

Julie: Americans won’t tolerate much more. Americans were already hard hit by inflation before Trump set foot in the Oval Office. Trump’s policies will make that problem much worse.

Mike: The increased costs will impact people’s monthly budgets.

Q: What does it tell us that members of his own party, right-wing media and influencers were pushing Trump to pivot?

Julie: MAGA is a cult, not a political movement. As for members of his party, they are more scared of a Trump-promoted, Musk-funded primary than they are of their own voters.

Mike: The people who influenced him were not the sycophants in Washington. The people who screamed were titans of finance like Jamie Dimon and Bill Ackman. Trump deeply respects and is moved by the opinions of people richer than he. When true business leaders who actually know how the economy works started speaking out about how these tariffs were idiotic and seemed to follow no real game plan, Trump hedged.

Q: What do you want us to watch for as the tariffs saga continues?

Julie: Don’t become the boiled frog and think any of this is normal, as Trump continues to tamper with the global economy. Volatility is an opportunity for some people to get very rich but the rest of us will suffer tremendously. The dollar is down, investors no longer look at United States government bonds as a safe haven and the chaos will continue to rile the stock market. This is what happens when you elect an unstable person to the presidency. He makes the United States unstable too.

Mike: Watch the business leaders. Trump will follow them. Trump will turn to the business leaders who don’t actually need him and try to win their praise. That means he will work quickly to extend his first-term tax cuts that are set to expire. That will also kickoff the debate on things like the SALT deduction and cuts to Medicaid. This will be a major domestic policy battle that will be played on Trump’s terms, because it is an economic battle.

title: Trump’s Impact on Japan and ASEAN - (Published 7 hour(s), 7 minute(s) ago)
content: For Asia, the most significant revelation has been Trump’s rejection of economic globalism and his clear inclination towards protectionism. Tariffs are often regarded as a form of “transactional” ...
resumen: Since the second Trump administration was inaugurated, the world has watched with a mix of hope and anxiety as U.S. domestic and foreign policies have departed wildly from long-established norms. President Donald Trump’s claim that the U.S. has borne an excessive burden, along with demands for greater contributions from Europe, Japan, and other allies, and even comments that undermine the alliances themselves, have shaken the unity that had been painstakingly sought by the Biden administration. With his deep distrust of international institutions, Trump has already signed an executive order withdrawing the U.S. from the UN Commission on Human Rights. Meanwhile, the dismantling of USAID has sent shockwaves through aid sectors across the globe. For Asia, the most significant revelation has been Trump’s rejection of economic globalism and his clear inclination towards protectionism. Tariffs are often regarded as a form of “transactional” diplomacy: high tariffs might occasionally be threatened, but provided demands are met they are ultimately not implemented. Trump sent shockwaves around the world by announcing – and then suspending – what he called “reciprocal tariffs,” which were in fact calculated based on U.S. trade deficits with its individual trading partners. In minutes, Trump had shredded the free and open economic order supported by the GATT/WTO system. These abrupt shifts in U.S. economic policy have raised serious concerns in East Asia and regional industry, which relies on supply chains built upon open cross-border business. While China has made rapid gains, the U.S. remains the world’s preeminent superpower. Moving forward, however, it is clear that the U.S. will pursue its own interests rather than being the primary pillar of the global order, as it has been throughout the post-Cold War period. It should be noted that this shift to the kind of behavior historically more usually been associated with great powers did not begin with the Trump administration, but is in fact a long-term trend. Nonetheless, Trump’s policies in particular have upended alliance networks, international institutions, the economy, and universal values across multiple fields. They have also made clear just how dependent Asia and the rest of the world have been on the U.S. With rapidly rising uncertainty within the regional order in Asia, Japan and ASEAN countries need to work together more closely than ever before. Still, their cooperation does not change the reality that they remain heavily dependent on the United States. For its part, Japan is part of an alliance and is highly reliant on the U.S. for its own security. Since China’s emergence as a major power, Japan has stepped up security cooperation with the U.S. in a number of areas. The Philippines also relies heavily on the U.S. for security, particularly compared to other ASEAN countries. Thailand is a treaty ally of the U.S., while Singapore and Malaysia have informally worked with the U.S. on defense, seeking to maintain a continued U.S. presence in Southeast Asia as a counter to China. However, neither country is as closely aligned with the U.S. in defense as Japan is. There are significant differences between Japan and Southeast Asia in the realm of values. Singapore’s Bilahari Kausikan, a former diplomat and well-known commentator, has argued (in Foreign Affairs, for instance) that Trump’s efforts to dismantle democratic institutions in the U.S. are not a major concern in Southeast Asia, where skepticism toward Western values has always been present. Japan is different. While skepticism and resistance to a Western-centric world do exist, postwar Japan has embraced the values of advanced democratic countries as a model. It has achieved these values to some extent and has built a peaceful, democratic society. This achievement has now become a part of Japan’s national identity. For many Japanese people, it is hard to turn away from what is happening in the U.S., which they have long seen as a model. Tokyo now needs to deal with a burgeoning trade war between the U.S. and China, together with sharp shifts in U.S. policy. Japan is not part of a regional organization like ASEAN, which acts as a buffer against external pressures and challenges. It is true that the active independent diplomacy of ASEAN countries, such as Indonesia’s accession to BRICS, is notable, and this raises the question of how much longer ASEAN centrality can be maintained. Still, it was interesting to note that in February, Malaysia, acting as ASEAN chair, alluded to plans for a U.S.-ASEAN summit aimed at expressing regional opinions on U.S. tariff policies. Irrespective of whether this initiative comes to anything, ASEAN countries do at least have a framework for coordinating individual opinions on external challenges and negotiating with outside powers collectively. This is something Japan lacks. While recognizing these differences, both Japan and ASEAN need to cooperate to create a highly predictable strategic environment within the region and work to keep the economic order as free and as open as possible. That will require a multifaceted and sophisticated  diplomatic approach that involves strengthening partnerships with major powers, middle powers, and small countries. Now more than ever it is vital that Japan and ASEAN countries strengthen partnerships. OBA Mie is a professor at Kanagawa University.

title: Thousands laid off at Canadian auto plants as workers pay the price for Trump’s trade war - (Published 11 hour(s), 38 minute(s) ago)
content: Like the UAW in the United States, Unifor is seeking to line workers up behind the global trade war, whipping up flag-waving nationalism and supporting tariff measures whose cost will be borne by ...
resumen:
Thousands of workers at Canadian auto plants have been laid off due to the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s trade war.

General Motors announced that electric van production at its CAMI assembly plant in Ingersoll, Ontario will wind down beginning April 14, leading to the layoff of all 1,200 workers at the CAMI plant until October, with only about 700 workers returning in the fall.

Stellantis "temporarily paused" its operations at its Windsor, Ontario assembly plant for at least two weeks, idling some 4,500 workers, and ordered a one-month halt in production at its Toluca Assembly Plant in Mexico. This resulted in the layoff of 900 workers in two supporting transmission plants in Kokomo, Indiana, and at Warren and Sterling Heights stamping plants in Michigan.

Unifor President Lana Payne in Canada and UAW President Shawn Fain in the United States have doubled down on their reactionary nationalist programs.

Flavio Volpe, CEO of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association, has said that up to 12,000 more Canadian auto parts workers are now “off the job” due to Stellantis’ production pauses.

Under the terms of the current pattern contract, autoworkers at the Canadian assembly plants of the Detroit Three who are on layoff receive just 70 percent of their normal wages through Supplemental Unemployment Benefits (SUB).

During an EV refit in 2022, hundreds of laid off workers at GM CAMI plant were forced to sign up at local food banks.

At GM’s Propulsion plant in St. Catharines, the workforce has been cut in half and now sits at 600 workers.

At GM’s Oshawa assembly operation, some 3,000 workers have learned that GM management has announced plans to hire an unspecified number of temporary employees at its Fort Wayne, Indiana, assembly plant.
