title: Not just products, Trump’s tariffs are affecting trade in services too - (Published 8 hour(s), 42 minute(s) ago)
content: The US tariffs are shaking up global trade, but the effect won’t stop at physical goods. Here's how it will affect trade in services.
resumen:
Trump’s new tariffs are shaking up global trade, and the impact won’t stop at physical goods. The US president has granted a 90-day pause on tariffs for many trading partners, dialing duties back to a 10% baseline, but not for China. A steep 145% tariff has just been enforced effective immediately, escalating tensions in the US-China trade relationship. The ripple effects on global trade in services are significant.

Trade in services refers to the sale and delivery of intangible products such as consulting, education, banking, insurance, IT, cloud services, and digital advertising. In 2023, global exports of commercial services reached US$7.3 trillion. Leading service exporters include the US, the EU, the UK, China, and India. The US exported US$1.1 trillion in services last year and recorded a US$295 billion trade surplus in services.

Tariffs don’t directly apply to services, but their indirect impact can be far-reaching. In March 2025, the US service sector posted its slowest growth since June 2024. Analysts point to rising uncertainty, declining consumer demand, and fears of broader economic contagion from the new tariff regime.

When the cost of goods rises, consumers buy less, prompting companies to cut back on advertising budgets. Analysts warn this could impact revenues for global giants like Meta and Google. Wedbush tech analyst Dan Ives says that if you cannibalise 10 to 15% of demand, that could cut digital advertising spend significantly.

Rising input costs lead to higher menu prices. As prices climb, consumer demand falls. Platforms like Uber Eats, Deliveroo and DoorDash may raise fees or reduce delivery zones.

Services also rely on goods, particularly hardware, devices, and infrastructure. A cloud computing provider in Singapore depends on servers assembled in China. A German fintech firm may use semiconductors sourced from Taiwan or Korea.

Governments may respond with regulatory hurdles, investment restrictions, or data localisation rules. China has previously responded to tariffs by limiting access to sectors like entertainment, education, and tech. Indian IT firms could pick up outsourcing contracts as US-China tensions push companies to look elsewhere for stable partners.

The global services economy is anything but insulated. Services are now vulnerable to cost pressures, strategic realignments, and geopolitical fallout. Businesses in the services sector must stay agile: diversify operational footprints, monitor policy shifts closely, and build contingency plans.

title: Trump Signals New Tariffs on Chips, Calling Exclusions Temporary - (Published 11 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: On Friday, the administration carved out an exception for a variety of electronics from the steep taxes now applied to Chinese imports.
resumen:
President Trump signaled on Sunday that he would pursue new tariffs on the powerful computer chips inside smartphones and other technologies, just two days after his administration excluded a variety of electronics from the steep import taxes recently applied on goods arriving from China.

The reprieve for technology companies arrived in the form of a Customs and Border Protection rule issued late Friday that spared high-tech imports from Mr. Trump’s so-called reciprocal tariffs, including those on China.

While the president paused a set of punishing levies on nearly 60 countries last week, his administration has forged ahead with a new 145 percent tax on Chinese exports, announcing it after Beijing retaliated against the United States.

The exclusions in the C.B.P. rule covered a wide slate of products, such as computers, smartphones, modems and flash drives, and it represented a major victory for Apple, and other U.S. technology giants, which rely on Chinese factories to help manufacture important components and popular devices.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump and his top aides cast the exemptions in a different light, framing them as only a temporary break while the government prepares more targeted import taxes on key technologies.

The administration is expected to take the first step toward enacting the new tariffs as soon as next week, opening an investigation to determine the effects of semiconductor imports on national security.

The approach appears to mirror the process that yielded Mr. Trump’s tariffs on other specific products and sectors, including the high fees he imposed on foreign cars and auto parts this year.

On social media, the president signaled Sunday that the scope of his next inquiry would be broad, “taking a look at Semiconductors and the WHOLE ELECTRONICS SUPPLY CHAIN in the upcoming National Security Tariff Investigations.”

Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, said earlier Sunday on ABC’s “This Week” that Mr. Trump could announce new tariffs “in the next month or two” that would target not only semiconductors but also pharmaceutical imports.

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told CNN’s “State of the Union” that it was “always the case” that some of these high-tech imports would be subject to their own tariffs, separate from those broadly imposed on countries in response to their trade practices.

Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, described the move on CBS’s “Face the Nation” as more of a mechanical change, saying of semiconductors that it is “not that they won’t be subject to tariffs” but that they are being done under a “different regime.”

The Trump administration had already excluded various types of semiconductors from the reciprocal tariffs as of April 2.

Some investors and chief executives publicly praised the decision to walk back tariffs on electronics, which represent roughly a quarter of U.S. imports from China.

Asked about the possibility of upcoming tariffs on chips on Saturday, Mr. Trump said, “I’ll give you that answer on Monday.”

Dan Ives, an analyst for Wedbush Securities, said in a note to investors on Sunday that “the mass confusion created by this constant news flow out of the White House is dizzying for the industry and investors and creating massive uncertainty and chaos for companies trying to plan their supply chain, inventory and demand.”

For Apple, in particular, the tit for tat between the United States and China caused the tech giant to lose more than $770 billion in market capitalization in just the opening days of Mr. Trump’s trade war.

title: Trump plans separate levy on exempted electronics amid trade war, Lutnick says - (Published 15 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said on Sunday that smartphones, computers and some other electronics, just exempted from steep tariffs on imports from China, would face ...
resumen:
U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said on Sunday that smartphones, computers and some other electronics, just exempted from steep tariffs on imports from China, would face separate new duties along with semiconductors within the next two months.

Lutnick's comments on ABC's "This Week" on critical technology products were the latest twist in President Donald Trump's tariff plans, which have upended the global trading order and roiled financial markets since they were announced on April 2, which Trump branded as "Liberation Day."

Late on Friday the Trump administration granted exclusions from the steep reciprocal tariffs on smartphones and a set of other electronics products, which was seen as a big break for technology firms such as Apple and Dell Technologies that rely on imports from China.

Trump's back-and-forth on tariffs has ratcheted up the uncertainty faced by investors and businesses, prompting the wildest swings on Wall Street since the COVID pandemic of 2020. The benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 index is down more than 10% since Trump took office on January 20.

Lutnick said Trump would enact "a special focus-type of tariff" on smartphones, computers and other electronics products in a month or two, alongside sectoral tariffs targeting semiconductors and pharmaceuticals. The new duties would fall outside Trump's so-called reciprocal tariffs, under which levies on Chinese imports climbed to 125% this week, he said.

Lutnick said in the interview on ABC, predicting that the levies would bring production of those products to the United States.

Lutnick's comments appeared to go beyond what was communicated on Saturday, when a White House official told media that Trump would launch a new national security trade investigation into semiconductors soon that could lead to other new tariffs.

Beijing increased its own tariffs on U.S. imports to 125% on Friday in response.

In a notice to shippers late on Friday, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency published a list of tariff codes excluded from the import taxes. It featured 20 product categories, including computers, laptops, disc drives, semiconductor devices, memory chips and flat panel displays.

For the Chinese imports, the exclusion of the tech products applies only to Trump's reciprocal tariffs, which reached 125% this week. Trump's prior 20% duties on all Chinese imports that he said were related to the fentanyl crisis remain in place.

title: China Warns U.S. Public as Trump’s Tariffs Hit Hard - (Published 13 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: Tensions have increased as a result of the long trade dispute; China has accused the United States of economic force and warned that the tariffs will ultimately impact American consumers more than ...
resumen:
China has sent a clear message to the American people by calling the rising tariffs imposed by former President Donald Trump a “tax on Americans.” The declaration coincides with the two world superpowers’ escalating trade war, in which both sides are imposing high tariffs on one another’s products. Beijing has responded with its own tariffs, which have a substantial effect on both countries’ industries and consumers, despite Trump’s defense that the duties are an essential step in combating China’s claimed unfair trade practices. Tensions have increased as a result of the long trade dispute; China has accused the United States of economic force and warned that the tariffs will ultimately impact American consumers more than Beijing. The effects on the economy are becoming more apparent as the tariff rates rise to levels that were never before seen.

The trade war between the U.S. and China has reached new heights in 2025, with Trump’s administration imposing a staggering 145% tariff on Chinese goods. In response, China has retaliated with its own 125% tariff on American imports. This tit-for-tat escalation has created a volatile economic environment, disrupting global supply chains and increasing costs for businesses and consumers alike.

China’s Ministry of Commerce has described the U.S.’s approach as a “mistake on top of a mistake,” emphasizing that such measures are unsustainable in the long term. The ministry also accused Trump of using tariffs as a political tool rather than an economic strategy, claiming that these policies are designed to appeal to his voter base rather than address genuine trade imbalances.

The tariffs have had far-reaching consequences, particularly for American industries reliant on Chinese imports. From electronics to agricultural products, businesses are grappling with higher costs that are often passed on to consumers. Meanwhile, Chinese exporters are also feeling the strain as demand from the U.S. declines due to inflated prices.

One of the most significant criticisms of Trump’s tariff policy is its impact on American consumers. Many essential goods imported from China—such as electronics, clothing, and household items—have become more expensive due to the increased tariffs. Analysts warn that these additional costs are effectively a tax on American households, reducing their purchasing power and contributing to inflation.

Businesses have also been hit hard by the trade war. Small and medium-sized enterprises that rely on Chinese suppliers are struggling to absorb the higher costs, leading some to downsize operations or shut down entirely. Even larger corporations are not immune; industries such as automotive manufacturing and technology have reported significant disruptions in their supply chains.

Farmers in the U.S., who were already grappling with fluctuating commodity prices, have been particularly affected by China’s retaliatory tariffs on agricultural products like soybeans, wheat, and pork. These measures have reduced export opportunities for American farmers, exacerbating financial difficulties in rural communities.

China has capitalized on this discontent by highlighting how Trump’s policies are harming his own constituents. Beijing has strategically targeted industries in states that supported Trump during his previous campaigns, aiming to create political pressure ahead of upcoming elections.

The consequences of the U.S.-China trade conflict are becoming more obvious as it escalates. Although Trump’s tariffs are intended to alleviate long-standing complaints about China’s trade policies, American firms and consumers have faced serious difficulties as a result of their implementation.

China’s warning that these tariffs are “just a tax on Americans” underscores the broader implications of this conflict. With both sides digging in their heels, finding a path toward de-escalation will be critical to preventing further economic damage.

In the end, a practical leadership style and an ability to put long-term stability ahead of immediate political advantages will be needed to end this trade war. However, as both countries deal with the consequences of their escalating tariff disputes, the future is still unclear.

title: Why don’t we learn history’s lessons? - (Published 21 hour(s), 54 minute(s) ago)
content: Why don’t we learn history’s lessons?
resumen: US President Donald Trump has unleashed a tariff offensive against every country in the world, arguing that the United States has been unfairly treated, luring away investments and jobs, and claiming his strategies are designed to rebalance trading relationships and bring jobs back to the US. Tariff offences are one form of trade war, which have been used in the past with disastrous consequences, such as the Fordney-McCumber Tariff measures of 1922, introduced by President Warren Harding, that raised the average tariff on American imports to 38 per cent, leading to huge price increases, loss of market confidence, stock market decline, and the Great Depression of the 1930s, which left 15 million Americans out of work. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1947 and the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995 were established to foster economic growth and avoid a repeat of Fordney-McCumber. Trump argues that countries all over the world are taking unfair advantage of the huge American market with clever fiscal measures, unfair labour policies, and currency manipulation. Manufacturers and producers are cost-sensitive and will locate their plants where they are able to produce efficiently and at the lowest cost, whether it is in Mexico, China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, or India. The effect of Trump’s tariff offensive in a country that is so import-dependent (trade deficit of US$1.2 trillion) is that consumers will pay more and, consequently, buy less. The global supply chain involves the production and trade efforts of manufacturers in several countries. China is likely to pursue new trade arrangements with the European Union, Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Trump’s gutting of its foreign aid programmes leaves it less leverage to pressure countries in these regions to stay away from China. Some spokespersons insist that these new tariffs are firm and are there to stay, while others state that they provide a basis for negotiations. Trump’s moves and the retaliatory responses of several other major countries have effectively left the WTO moribund. Trump has slapped a 10 per cent tariff on Jamaican exports to the US. Ghana enjoys a huge trade surplus with the US, but its exports, too, have been slapped with a 10 per cent tariff. The US no longer holds a monopoly over technology and innovation. Cracks have emerged among senior Republicans regarding the efficacy of Trump’s tariff offensive. Senator Ted Cruz was strident in his condemnation. Senator John Kennedy declared that this is now Trump’s economy and if his policies succeed he deserves the credit, but if they fail, he has to accept the blame. Elon Musk, through a social media post by his brother, inveighed against the tariff measures and declared that its chief architect, Peter Navarro, despite his Harvard PhD, had not ever built s**t. Demonstrations are increasing across the US against Trump’s policies.

title: Trump’s China tariff shocks U.S. importers: a Chicago-area CEO calls it ‘end of days’ - (Published 11 hour(s), 21 minute(s) ago)
content: Rick Woldenberg runs Learning Resources in Vernon Hills, which specializes in educational toys. The company makes 2,400 products in China and employs about 500 people. He says the business is reeling ...
resumen:
Rick Woldenberg, CEO of Learning Resources in Vernon Hills, which specializes in educational toys, says the business is reeling since punitive tariffs were imposed by President Donald Trump. The company makes 2,400 products in China and employs about 500 people. Woldenberg calculates that the latest tariffs on China will push Learning Resource’s tariff bill from $2.3 million last year to $100.2 million in 2025. President Donald Trump raised the levy to 54% and then to 145%.
China produces 97% of America’s imported baby carriages, 96% of its artificial flowers and umbrellas, 95% of its fireworks, 93% of its children’s coloring books and 90% of its combs.
Joe Jurken, founder of the ABC Group in Milwaukee, says American consumers got addicted to cheap pricing.
David French, senior vice president of government affairs at the National Retail Foundation, says the consequences of tariffs at this scale could be apocalyptic at many levels.
The Yale University Budget Lab estimates the tariffs that Trump has announced globally since taking office would lower U.S. economic growth by 1.1 percentage points in 2025.
The University of Michigan’s survey of consumer sentiment found Americans expect long-term inflation to reach 4.4%, up from 4.1% last month.
Stephen Roach, former chairman of Morgan Stanley Asia and now at Yale Law School’s China Center, says consumers have figured this out as well.
Isaac Larian, the founder of MGA Entertainment, which makes L.O.L. and Bratz dolls, says no business can run on uncertainty. His company gets 65% of its product from Chinese factories, a share he is trying to winnow down to 40% by the end of the year. MGA also manufactures in India, Vietnam and Indonesia. Larian estimates the price of Bratz dolls could go from $15 to $40 and L.O.L. dolls could double to $20 by this year’s holiday season.
Marc Rosenberg, founder and CEO of The Edge Desk in Deerfield, Illinois, invested millions of dollars to develop $1,000 ergonomic chairs, which were to start production in China next month.
Woldenberg’s company in Vernon Hills, Illinois, has been in the family since 1916. It was started by his grandfather as a laboratory supply company and evolved over the years into Learning Resources. The company specializes in educational toys such as Botley: The Coding Robot and the brainteaser Kanoodle. It employs about 500 people — 90% in the U.S. — and makes about 2,400 products in China.

resumen: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) cut Singapore’s growth forecast for 2025 to “0.0 to 2.0 per cent” on concerns that the US-China tariff war could induce a global economic slowdown. This is a downgrade from the 1 per cent and 3 per cent range previously. MTI said on April 14 that the external demand outlook for Singapore for the rest of the year has weakened significantly, leading to a deterioration in the outlook of outward-oriented sectors in Singapore, particularly the manufacturing sector. The pullback in global trade will similarly dampen the growth of the transportation & storage sector. The finance and insurance sector could see weaker trading activity. The uncertain economic backdrop will likely dampen firms’ capital investment spending and constrain credit intermediation activity. The growth of payments firms could moderate. Taking these factors as well as the performance of the Singapore economy in the first quarter into account, MTI has decided to downgrade Singapore’s GDP growth forecast for 2025 to “0.0 to 2.0 per cent”. The Singapore economy grew by 3.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the first quarter of 2025. Bloomberg’s consensus estimate was for a 4.7 per cent year-on-year growth and a 0.3 per cent contraction on a quarter on quarter basis as of April 8. title: MAS eases Singapore dollar policy to help economy weather Trump’s tariff storm - (Published 8 hour(s), 38 minute(s) ago)
content: MAS also lowered its core inflation forecast to average 0.5–1.5 per cent in 2025. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has further reduced the pace of Singapore dollar’s trade-weighted appreciation in response to easing inflation and rising risks to economic growth amid US president Donald Trump’s tariffs assault on global trade.

MAS is now expecting core inflation to average 0.5 per cent to 1.5 per cent in 2025, down from 1 per cent to 2 predicted in January 2025.

MAS will continue with the policy of a modest and gradual appreciation of the S$NEER policy band, but the rate of appreciation will be reduced slightly.

The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded its forecast for full-year 2025 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to a range of zero per cent to 2 per cent, from 1 per cent to 3 per cent previously. Singapore’s GDP grew 4.4 per cent in 2024.

The manufacturing sector shrank 4.9 per cent quarter on quarter, followed by construction at minus 2.3 per cent.

The Singapore dollar was up 0.2 per cent to 1.3164 per US dollar as at 9:14am.

The Singdollar had jumped 1 per cent against the US dollar on Friday (April 11), bringing its year-to-date gains to 3.1 per cent against the greenback.

In January MAS reduced the pace o S$Neer appreciation for the first time since 2020, as core inflation eased.

In February 2025 core inflation came in at 0.6 per cent, down from a peak of 5.6 per cent in January 2023.

The Singapore’s Straits Times Index closed down 1.8 per cent at 3,512.53 points on April 11, taking the benchmark down 8.2 per cent over the week.

The local dollar has dropped this year by about 5.6 per cent versus the Japanese yen and 5.5 per cent against the euro. Still, the Singapore dollar has gained 1.1 per cent versus the British pound year-to-date and is up 2 per cent against the Malaysian ringgit.

title: Trump Has Added Risk to the Surest Bet in Global Finance - (Published 15 hour(s), 12 minute(s) ago)
content: Shocked by Trump’s trade war, foreign investors are selling U.S. government bonds, long the world’s safe haven.
resumen: Investors buy U.S. Treasuries on the assumption that the federal government will endure and stand by its debts. Turmoil in bond markets last week revealed the extent to which President Trump has shaken faith in that basic proposition, challenging the previously unimpeachable solidity of U.S. government debt. His trade war, now focused intently on China, has raised the prospect of a worldwide economic downturn while damaging American credibility as a responsible steward of peace and prosperity. An erosion of faith in the governance of the world’s largest economy appears at least in part responsible for the sharp sell-off in the bond market in recent days. Last week, the yield on the closely watched 10-year Treasury bond soared to roughly 4.5 percent from just below 4 percent. At the same time, the value of the American dollar has been falling. Hedge funds and other financial players have sold holdings. Some fear that China’s central bank, which commands $3 trillion in foreign exchange reserves, including $761 billion in U.S. Treasury debt, could be selling as a form of retaliation for American tariffs. One reason appears to be an effective downgrading of the American place in global finance, from a safe haven to a source of volatility and danger. The Trump administration has championed tariffs in the name of bringing manufacturing jobs back to the United States. For years, economists have worried about an abrupt drop in the willingness of foreigners to buy and hold United States government debt, yielding a sharp and destabilizing increase in American interest rates. Because the United States has long served as the global economy’s safe harbor, the government has reliably found takers for its debt at lower rates of interest. Critics have long argued that this model is both unsustainable and destructive. The economist Michael Pettis wrote last week in an opinion piece in The Financial Times. Mr. Trump has warned companies that the only way to avoid his tariffs is to set up factories in the United States, while lifting trade protectionism to levels not seen in more than a century. Mr. Trump has broken with eight decades of faith in the benefits of global trade. The tariffs threaten existing jobs at factories that depend on imported parts to make their products. The levies have been set at rates seemingly plucked at random, economists said. Simon Johnson, a Nobel laureate economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, “What the market really didn’t like was the random crazy math of the tariffs.” The immediate consequence of higher interest rates on United States bonds is an increase in what the federal government must pay creditors to keep current on its debts. The broader effects are harder to predict, yet could metastasize into a recession. For years, foreign holders of American bonds have sought to diversify into other storehouses for savings. Europe and its common currency, the euro, now seem enhanced as a part of the global financial realm. The Chinese government has long sought to elevate the place of its currency, the renminbi.

title: Is AGOA gone with Trump’s new tariffs? - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: Analysts say the new tariffs suggest that the renewal of the initiative is extremely unlikely COVER STORY | THE INDEPENDENT & AGENCIES | In what has been described as one of the most disruptive ...
resumen:
On April 2, 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump unveiled sweeping tariffs on nearly all imports, including a 10% across-the-board tariff on all imports, alongside targeted tariffs of 34% on Chinese goods, 20% on European products, 24% on Japan, and 10% on the UK.

In Africa, the move appears to signal the end of the AGOA (African Growth and Opportunity Act) trade deal.

A 50% reciprocal trade tariff on Lesotho is the highest levy on Trump’s target economies. Lesotho's exports to the United States totaled $237 million in 2024, accounting for more than 10% of its GDP.

Lesotho charges 99% tariffs on American goods, according to the U.S. administration.

Other African countries hit with extra tariffs include 47% for Madagascar, 40% for Mauritius, 37% for Botswana and 30% for South Africa. Nigerian exports will be hit too – at a rate of 14%.

Kenya, Ghana, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Uganda, Senegal and Liberia were among those countries whose exports to the US will be subject to the baseline tariff of 10%.

Analysts say the new tariffs suggest that the renewal of the initiative, known as the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), is extremely unlikely.

AGOA is a U.S. trade initiative passed in 2000 under former President Bill Clinton. It provides duty-free access to the U.S. market for thousands of products exported by eligible African countries. It has been renewed twice and is due to expire in September 2025.

African countries have been pushing for a 10-year extension.

The new tariffs have heightened the risk that AGOA may be scrapped altogether even before it expires.

Government officials from South Africa and Madagascar said they were waiting for clarity on whether the reciprocal tariffs announced by Trump will be applied to goods that are exported under AGOA.

AGOA’s extension requires a decision of the U.S. Congress and is thereafter signed into law by the U.S. President.

About 35 African countries are currently eligible.

A number of countries including South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Madagascar and Ethiopia have successfully used AGOA to boost exports to the U.S.

U.S. imports from AGOA beneficiaries peaked in 2008 at $82 billion and had fallen to $29.1 billion in 2024, according to the AGOA website.

Sectors such as South Africa’s automotive industry as well as Kenya and Lesotho’s clothing sectors would be hit hardest from a sudden rise in tariffs or non-renewal of AGOA.

Nigel Green, CEO of global financial advisory giant deVere Group, said Trump “peddles in economic delusion” and risks triggering a dangerous global slowdown. deVere Group has a network of offices around the world, more than 80,000 clients, and $14bn under advisement.

The OECD recently warned that if the U.S. and its trading partners raise tariffs by 10 percentage points, global GDP could fall by 0.3% within three years, while inflation could rise by an average of 0.4 percentage points each year over the same period.

El 29 de mayo de 2024, el Consejo de Ministros aprobó el proyecto de Ley de Eficiencia del Sector Público, que busca mejorar la gestión y el funcionamiento de las administraciones públicas. La ley se estructura en tres títulos:

*   **Título I: Eficiencia Organizativa.** Introduce medidas para simplificar la estructura administrativa, reducir cargas burocráticas y mejorar la coordinación entre las diferentes administraciones.
*   **Título II: Eficiencia en la Gestión de los Recursos Humanos.** Se enfoca en la optimización de la plantilla, la formación de los empleados públicos y la promoción de la igualdad y la conciliación.
*   **Título III: Eficiencia en la Gestión Económico-Financiera.** Contempla medidas para mejorar la planificación presupuestaria, la gestión de los contratos públicos y el control del gasto.

El proyecto de ley incluye la creación de la Oficina Nacional de Evaluación, que se encargará de evaluar el impacto de las políticas públicas y proponer mejoras. También se prevé la creación de un registro de altos cargos y directivos del sector público, con el objetivo de aumentar la transparencia y la rendición de cuentas.

title: Here’s How Trump Plans to Take Control of Greenland - (Published 13 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump’s plan to acquire Greenland is very real, and it apparently involves convincing the country to hand itself over to U.S. control.
resumen:
Donald Trump's plan to acquire Greenland involves convincing the country to hand itself over to U.S. control. The White House National Security Council has met "several times" to make Trump’s desires for the arctic island a reality. The effort is driven by a massive P.R. campaign consisting of spending federal dollars on advertising and social media campaigns with hopes of persuading Greenland’s 57,000 residents to annex themselves for America.

Greenland is a semiautonomous territory of Denmark. After months of pressure from the Trump family, including an embarrassing stunt in which Donald Trump Jr. reportedly convinced homeless residents to wear MAGA merchandise in exchange for food, and an effort in the U.S. Congress to rename the territory “Red, White, and Blueland,” Greenland’s various political parties set aside their differences in March to unite under a singular goal: opposing U.S. aggression.

Demokraatit Party leader Jens-Frederik Nielsen said, "We don’t want to be Americans. No, we don’t want to be Danes. We want to be Greenlanders, and we want our own independence in the future, and we want to build our own country by ourselves.”

In January, the chair of Greenland’s parliamentary Foreign and Security Policy Committee Pipaluk Lynge warned the U.S. not to “invade” the nation.

A late January poll by pollster Verian found that 85 percent of Greenland’s residents do not want to become part of the United States. Just 6 percent were in favor of the switch, while 8 percent were undecided, according to The Guardian.

In a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte last month, Trump said, "We need [Greenland] for international security. That whole area is becoming very important, for a lot of reasons. The routes are very direct to Asia, to Russia, and you have ships all over the place. We have to have protection. So, we’re going to have to make a deal on that, and Denmark is not able to do that, and you know, Denmark is very far away, and really has nothing to do. What happened? A boat landed there 200 years ago or something and they say they have rights to it, I don’t know if that’s true, I don’t think it is, actually.”

In an address to Congress last month, Trump clarified his intention: “One way or the other, we’re going to get it.”

Donald Trump stated that no country would be getting “off the hook” on tariffs, despite a 90-day reprieve on some levies.

Global markets have been on a rollercoaster since Trump’s April 3 tariffs announcement.

Most nations will now face a baseline 10% tariff for the near-three-month period – except China.

US levies imposed on China have risen to 145% and Beijing set a retaliatory 125% band on US imports.

Trump’s administration has said it intends to negotiate trade deals, including with China.

Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform that “NOBODY is getting ‘off the hook’ for the unfair Trade Balances, and Non-Monetary Tariff Barriers, that other Countries have used against us, especially not China, which, by far, treats us the worst!”.

Trump issued exemptions for Chinese-made semiconductors and electronics.

Trump asserted that there was “no tariff ‘exception’” on those products, saying that they remained subject to a 20% rate in “a different tariff ‘bucket’”.

Beijing’s Commerce Ministry said the weekend’s move only “represents a small step” and insisted that the Trump administration should “completely cancel” the whole tariff strategy.

Some of the exempted consumer electronics are targeted for upcoming sector-specific tariffs.

Trump has said he will give “very specific” details on Monday, UST, and his commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, said semiconductor tariffs would likely be in place “in a month or two”.

Lutnick said pharmaceutical products would “also be outside the reciprocal tariffs”.

The White House says Trump remains optimistic about securing a deal with China.

Trump’s trade representative Jamieson Greer told CBS Face the Nation that “we don’t have any plans” for talks between the US President and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping.

Xi on Monday kicks off a five-day Southeast Asia tour for talks with the leaders of Vietnam, Malaysia and Cambodia.

The fallout from Trump’s tariffs has sent particular shockwaves through the US economy, with investors dumping government bonds, the dollar tumbling and consumer confidence plunging.

Wall Street billionaires have openly criticised the tariff strategy as damaging and counterproductive.

The White House insists the aggressive policy is bearing fruit, saying dozens of countries have already opened trade negotiations to secure a deal before the 90-day pause ends.

Greer told CBS News that “We’re working around the clock, day and night, sharing paper, receiving offers and giving feedback to these countries.”

The author identifies this as a direct, overt violation of the law and contradicts the very reason that the APA exists. If the Supreme Court lets him get away with it, another judicial guardrail against a Trump autocracy will fall away. Trump stacked the Supreme Court in his first term. On April 2, Trump declared an emergency under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977, which gives him the power to bypass Congress for an emergency "originating outside the United States". The "emergency" that allowed him to up-end the global trading system and end 80 years of US-led stability is merely the existence of trade deficits. There are 136 distinct powers delegated by Congress in the event of an emergency; only 13 require a declaration by Congress at the time. The US has become a gangster state.

title: US-China trade war: How India can turn crisis into opportunity - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: The escalation of the trade tensions between the US and China could bring significant gains to some sectors of India. The reduced reliance of US companies on Chinese goods makes India an attractive al ...
resumen:
The escalation of trade tensions between the US and China could bring significant gains to some sectors of India. The reduced reliance of US companies on Chinese goods makes India an attractive alternative. India being cautiously positioned amidst the US-China trade tensions faces both risks and opportunities.

The White House clarified that the levies on Chinese imports stand at 145 per cent—the 125 per cent tariff announced by President Donald Trump is in addition to the two hikes of 10 per cent post-Trump taking office. In 2023, China exported $463 billion in goods and services to the US, whereas the US export to China was $199 billion. The US imports from China include mobile phones worth $64.1 billion, computers and accessories worth $50.5 billion, electric and industrial equipment worth $46.2 billion, sporting and gaming goods worth $30.8 billion, car parts worth $15.5 billion, etc, and exports from the US to China include soybeans worth $12.8 billion, aircraft and parts worth $11.5 billion, pharmaceuticals worth $10 billion, semiconductors worth $99 billion, industrial machines worth $7.4 billion, crude oil and liquid and natural gases worth $12.1 billion, etc. The consequential trade deficit between the US and China was $295 billion. The Trump administration has exempted smartphones, computers and other electronics from its ‘reciprocal’ tariffs.

The manufacturing sector of India, particularly electronics, may face vulnerability due to its heavy reliance on Chinese goods. India, despite being the global leader in pharmaceuticals, heavily relies on China for raw materials. As much as 70 per cent of the raw material for the pharmaceutical industry of India, including antibiotics, vitamins, and paracetamol, comes from China. The automakers and steel producers of India may also face supply chain pressure due to potential Chinese dumping threatening local prices. China is the world’s largest exporter of steel, amounting to $88.3 billion. The redirections of cheap Chinese textiles to India would threaten India’s textile hubs like Tripura and Surat.

India is a leading supplier of generic drugs, accounting for around 20 per cent of the global supply of generic medicines. The American companies withdrawing from China would prefer India as their production hub due to the competitive labour cost compared to China. The US restriction on semiconductor exports to China would push firms to invest in India. In 2023 AMD has committed to investing $400 million in India, and Applied Materials, Inc., has announced its intention to build a collaborative engineering centre in Bangalore, India. Similarly, if China reduces importing US goods, India could step in to supply commodities like soybeans and cotton to China.

Xi Jinping’s ‘dragon-elephant tango’ message to President Draupadi Murmu reflects a strategic but friendly gesture from China. India and the US, through a technological partnership in the form of iCET (India-US Critical and Emerging Technology), aim to enhance national security and advance economic development.

If the tariff standoff remains consistent, the concern of electronics import reliance could be addressed with faster PLI (Production Linked Incentive) scheme execution. The Pharma API dependence could be reduced by boosting domestic API (Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient) production via PLI. The issue of textile, steel, and auto part dumping would have to be tackled by stricter anti-dumping duties and local sourcing mandates vis-à-vis incentivising synthetic fibre production in India.

India can either reduce supply chain dependency on China by taking critical policy action for the next 2-3 years or face prolonged supply chain pain.

title: China puts officials on wartime footing as Trump’s tariff tantrums stir Cold War tensions - (Published 20 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: Trump stunned the world with massive tariffs that he said would prevent countries like China from “ripping off” the US. Chinese leader Xi Jinping ditched official caution and issued a patriotic ...
resumen:
On April 2, Trump announced massive tariffs to prevent countries like China from “ripping off” the US.

Beijing has placed civilian officials on “wartime footing” and launched a global diplomatic offensive in response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s latest trade salvos.

Foreign and commerce ministry staff have reportedly been told to cancel vacations and remain on standby 24/7, while propaganda departments are circulating defiant messaging, including archival footage of Mao Zedong vowing never to yield.

The move follows Trump’s steep tariff hikes and marks a sharp shift from China’s previous efforts to de-escalate the dispute through compromise.

Bureaucrats in the foreign affairs and commerce ministries have reportedly been told to cancel vacations and stay on-call 24/7, while propaganda officials have spearheaded efforts to frame the response with defiant messaging including videos of Mao Zedong vowing never to yield, Reuters reported, citing multiple sources familiar with the strategy.

Beijing has now ramped up retaliatory tariffs and is reaching out to other nations targeted by US trade policy including European allies, Japan and South Korea, urging a coordinated response.

The United States has escalated its trade conflict with China dramatically, raising tariffs to 145% in response to what President Donald Trump labelled as Beijing’s “unfair trade practices.”

China retaliated with its own 125% tariffs.

A spokesperson for China’s embassy in Washington said in response to Reuters’ questions that Beijing did not want to fight trade wars “but is not scared of them.”

After the initial Chinese retaliation, Trump said: “China played it wrong, they panicked – the one thing they cannot afford to do!”

China’s foreign ministry has summoned many of the heads of its overseas missions back to Beijing for a special meeting held this week to coordinate the response, according to two Beijing-based diplomats.

China has also sent formal letters to government officials of other countries pressured by Trump to engage in trade negotiations.

China has approached some G20 governments with wording for a joint declaration voicing support for the multilateral trading system, an EU diplomat told Reuters.

Chinese officials also published on Musk’s X platform a clip of Chairman Mao giving a speech in 1953.

In the clip, Mao says peace is up to the Americans. “No matter how long this war is going to last, we’ll never yield,” he said. “We’ll fight until we completely triumph.”

title: Global trade dynamics amid US-China tariff war - (Published 13 hour(s), 32 minute(s) ago)
content: The impact of Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs (TRT) remains uncertain, but it has undeniably divided the world into three distinct blocs: the US, China, and the rest of the world (ROW) -- excluding ...
resumen: The impact of Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs (TRT) has divided the world into three blocs: the US, China, and the rest of the world (ROW), excluding Canada and Mexico. The US and China are in a tariff war. The bilateral trade in goods between the US and China faces the risk of being severed due to steep tariffs: a combined 125 percent plus 20 percent by the US against China, and a retaliatory 125 percent by China effective April 12, alongside the 15 percent tariff it enacted on March 10, 2025. Exports from alternative sources in the ROW are subject to a 10 percent TRT, but China imposes no equivalent tariff on them. The 10 percent TRT on countries outside the US and China is set to remain in effect for at least 90 days following the pause on April 10, 2025. In 2024, merchandise trade between the US and China totalled $583 billion, with $144 billion in US exports to China and $439 billion in imports from China to the US. China's share in US imports is forecasted to decrease from 14 percent to 4 percent (The Budget Lab, April 10, 2025), potentially creating approximately $167 billion in export opportunities for other nations to the US. China's exports to the US are predominantly machinery, electronics and telecommunications equipment, clothing, textiles and footwear. In 2024, Chinese imports from the US accounted for 5.5 percent of their total imports. If this share decreases in proportion to the decline projected in the US, it could drop to 1.5 percent, thereby generating $105 billion in export opportunities for other countries to China. US exports to China encompass a wide range of products, including electronics, machinery, nuclear reactors, agricultural goods, oil, vehicles, plastics, pharmaceutical products, perfumes, toiletries, and cosmetics. The estimates are partially invalidated by the exemption from TRT granted to smartphones, semiconductors, chips, laptops, computer monitors and various electronic parts, but the exemption does not include the 20 percent tariff on Chinese goods for China's alleged role in the fentanyl trade. Under the TRT regime, the US and China will seek identical goods or close substitutes from third countries. The wide gap between the US tariffs -- 10 percent TRT plus pre-exiting tariffs on most countries (total 25 percent in case of Bangladesh for instance) and 145 percent on Chinese goods except high tech items -- makes other countries particularly appealing during the current TRT regime. While a reduction in the 10 percent TRT is possible after the 90-day period, the ongoing tit-for-tat tariffs between the US and China are likely to persist beyond this timeframe. Fresh trade and investment opportunities will arise in sectors like textiles, footwear, machinery, and other categories within the broader US-China trade spectrum. US garment and footwear importers can establish partnerships with companies in alternative locations. US companies catering to Chinese consumers and producers often maintain production capacities outside the US. The ongoing trade war between the US and China may offer a modest boost to growth in the ROW, even as it dampens real GDP growth in both the US and China. Over the long term, not accounting for the latest exemptions, their economies were projected to shrink by 0.6 percent each, while the ROW could see a slight 0.07 percent increase in growth (The Budget Lab, ibid). Bangladesh, in particular, stands to benefit significantly, as US consumers face price hikes of 64 percent for apparel and 44 percent for textiles (The Budget Lab, ibid). The outcomes of ROW negotiations with the US over the next 90 days will be closely monitored by the Chinese government and global businesses.

title: The ladder in the chaos: An opportunity for India - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Donald Trump’s tariffs have unleashed chaos on the world order. Will India manage to climb up the ladder of opportunity?
resumen:
Donald Trump’s tariffs have unleashed chaos on the world order.
The US is the top importer in the world, with goods worth about $3.2 trillion landing up at its ports last year―that is almost as much as the total GDP of India.
Trump announced tariffs with sweeping import duties on almost all of America’s trading partners.
Vidya Mahambare, Union Bank Chair professor of economics and director (research) at Great Lakes Institute of Management, Chennai, said that if the new tariffs are not rolled back to some extent at least, there is a high chance the US economy itself will suffer significantly and the impact will not be limited to certain export sectors or certain countries, it will have larger impact globally, including on India.
Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that the “Liberation Day announcements by the US marks a seismic change in global order. The era of rules-based globalisation and free trade is over.”.
China’s exports to America was $83 billion more than American exports to China in 2000; last year this deficit had ballooned to nearly $300 billion.
China has imposed reciprocal tariffs.
Madhavi Arora, chief economist with Emkay Global, said that because it’s a retaliation from the US across the globe, the retaliation to the US will also be across the globe.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi sealed a deal to double bilateral trade to $500 billion by the end of this decade.
The countries might sign a bilateral trade agreement (BTA) by this autumn.
Ankit Jaipuria, co-founder of ZYOD, an export-oriented textile sector manufacturing firm, said that if India has an advantage in the near term with a less tariff than other exporting countries, to become more competitive the government should provide production-linked incentives and capital incentives to expand the manufacturing supply base.
Mrunmayee Joglekar, analyst at Asit C. Mehta Investment Intermediates, said that the Indian auto component industry generates 30 per cent of its revenues from exports, of which nearly 30 per cent is from the US.
Panckaj N. Umrania, executive director at KND, a steel maker, said that duty on Chinese steel in the US was 25 per cent; now it has been increased to 54 per cent.
Arora said that there will be a whole lot of simultaneous negotiations and that India has to be nimble, more strategic, and not just with the US and existing trade partners, but with new ones.
While India’s industrial capacity utilisation averages above 70 per cent for big industries, it can be as low as 33 per cent for small scale units.
Jaipuria said that what India needs to work upon is a focused process-oriented approach where it can provide cost benefit, cost efficiencies and reliability to global players.

title: How India can tackle Donald Trump’s tariff tantrums - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Former vice chairman of NITI Aayog, Rajiv Kumar, explains how the Donald Trump-induced tariff tantrums could affect India and outlines ways in which India should respond ...
resumen:
Rajiv Kumar, former vice chairman of NITI Aayog, explains how the Donald Trump-induced tariff tantrums could affect India and outlines ways in which India should respond.

India should not try and lead or even join any attempt for the restoration of the WTO institutional regime.

India should neither contemplate retaliating nor should it go ‘cap in hand’ looking for charitable discounts under the veneer of a bilateral trade agreement.

India should give up the myth that India benefits from a ‘strong rupee’.

The Reserve Bank in collaboration with the Central government should let the rupee depreciate sufficiently to absorb some of the hike in prices of our export goods that will happen as a result of the higher tariffs.

India should also try and put in place robust export promotion measures, which could be made an integral part of the production-linked incentive scheme.

Each state government may be encouraged to formulate its own export promotion policies.

These state-specific export promotion policies should now focus on the space opened up in the US market.

The Central government should partner with and assist state governments to identify ‘Anchor Investor’ in select sectors.

An in-depth review of these export promotion councils and subsequently assigning them specific outcome-based key performance indicators are required.

India and its states need to get their act together.

We need to bring the governments, private industry and the academia on the same platform for designing and implementing a robust and dynamic set of state specific export promotion policies.

The author is chairman of Pahlé India Foundation and former vice chairman of NITI Aayog.

resumen:
The US-China tariff war has entered a new phase due to Trump's recent decisions and Beijing's reaction, endangering the economies of both countries and the stability of the world economy.

US President Donald Trump announced a 5% baseline tariff on all imported goods on April 2 (April 5). The EU faced a 5% tariff, while countries like Vietnam (2%), Bangladesh (2%), Taiwan (2%), Japan (2%), and Lesotho (2%) were also affected. China responded with tariffs exceeding 100%. Trump retreated from tariffs on over 5 countries for 6 days but increased tariffs on Chinese goods to 5%. China increased customs tariffs on American goods by 5%. The White House announced total tariffs on imports of Chinese goods up to 2%. China has put a large US company on the list of unreliable institutions and increased economic cooperation with the European Union and the Southeast Asian Union (ASEAN).

The tariff war has affected the American and Chinese economies. In the United States, economic growth has slowed, with real GDP dropping by about half a percent in the first half of the year. US consumers have faced rising prices, costing an additional $2 annually per household. American farmers have faced a sharp decline in demand, with soybean exports declining by less than half. The automotive industry has faced increased costs and lost export markets. Great market analysts have warned that the continuation of this trend could enter the US economy by the end of the year.

China's economic growth has reached 5% this year, the lowest in the last two decades. Reducing exports to the United States, dropping domestic demand, and reducing private sector investment are key factors in this downtrend. The Yuan’s value has fallen to its lowest level since year 6. Millions of Chinese workers in export-oriented industries have been threatened by unemployment. China has tried to reduce its dependence on the US market by expanding its export markets to other countries such as members of ASEAN, Africa, and Latin America.

The tariff war between the United States and China has had significant impacts on the world trade process. The increase in tariffs has impaired the free flow of goods and capital, and global supply chains, especially in technology, automotive, medicine, and consumer goods, have become unstable. One of the most important consequences of these tensions is the increase in global inflation. This war has slowed global economic growth. The IMF and the World Bank have reported that these tensions could reduce the world’s GDP by up to a few percent.

The tariff war has accelerated the “economic worldwide” process or decline in world trade dependence. Countries have become more inclined to boost their domestic production or find new business partners. The impact of the tariff war is not just economic. These wars can weaken international organizations such as the World Trade Organization (WTO), exacerbate regional competitions, and create the basis for future political and military confrontation.

Observers believe that continuing or exacerbating trade tensions between the United States and China is a profound threat to the global economy and geopolitical order. A full-fledged trade war can reduce the world’s GDP in the long run. Raw material exporters suffer the most damage from this situation. Severe inflation, instability of financial markets, increased economic pressure on consumers, policy-making in economic decisions, and even the possibility of expanding conflicts to non-economic areas are among the worrying consequences of such a crisis.

Experts believe that the parties should return to the negotiating table and move towards multilateral agreements with European, Asian, and international institutions. Supporting the affected industries through financial facilitation policies and diversification to global supply chains can reduce the risk of over-dependence on a particular country.

title: US exempts tech imports in tariff step back - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: The move came as retaliatory Chinese import tariffs of 125 percent on US goods took effect Saturday, with Beijing standing defiant against its biggest trade partner.
resumen: The Trump administration has exempted a raft of consumer electronics from its import tariffs, offering relief to US tech firms and partially dialing down a trade war with China. A notice by the US Customs and Border Protection office said smartphones, laptops, memory chips and other products would be excluded from the global levies President Donald Trump rolled out a week ago. The move came as retaliatory Chinese import tariffs of 125 percent on US goods took effect Saturday. The exemptions will benefit US tech companies like Nvidia and Dell, as well as Apple. The exemptions will generally narrow the impact of the 145 percent tariffs Trump has imposed this year on Chinese goods entering the United States. US Customs data suggests the exempted items account for more than 20 percent of those Chinese imports, according to senior RAND researcher Gerard DiPippo. Semiconductors could still become a target of industry-specific tariffs Trump has suggested placing on imports from all countries. Trump said Saturday that he would give a “very specific” answer to the question of any future semiconductor levies on Monday. Washington and Beijing's escalating tariff battle has raised fears of an enduring trade war between the world's two largest economies and sent global markets into a tailspin. Investors are dumping government bonds, the dollar is tumbling and consumer confidence is plunging. Wall Street billionaires have openly criticized the whole tariff strategy as damaging and counter-productive. Daniel Ives, senior equity analyst at Wedbush Securities, called the US exemptions the "best news possible" for tech investors. The exclusions remove "a huge black cloud" that had threatened to take the US tech sector "back a decade" and significantly slow AI development, Ives said in a note. Many of the exempted products, including hard drives and computer processors, are not generally made in the United States. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt insisted that the likes of Apple and Nvidia were still "hustling to onshore their manufacturing in the United States" as soon as possible. New York University economist Nouriel Roubini posted Saturday on X that Trump's "exemptions will not reshore iPhones or tech goods and they will not reshore either cheap goods we can't and won't produce at home". Beijing has vowed not to give in to what it sees as bullying tactics, and President Xi Jinping stressed Friday that China was "not afraid." The US alone buys up 16.4 percent of Chinese exports, according to Beijing's trade data, making for total exchanges between the two countries worth $500 billion. China's Commerce Minister Wang Wentao told the head of the World Trade Organization (WTO) that US tariffs will "inflict serious harm" on poor nations. The White House says Trump remains "optimistic" about securing a deal with China.

title: Apple has few incentives to start making iPhones in US, despite Trump’s trade war with China - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: President Trump’s administration has been predicting its barrage of tariffs targeting China will push Apple into manufacturing the iPhone in the US. But that’s an unlikely scenario.
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s administration has been predicting its barrage of tariffs targeting China will push Apple into manufacturing the iPhone in the United States for the first time.

The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that it began building in China during the 1990s. It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build new plants in the US, and then confront Apple with economic forces that could triple the price of an iPhone, threatening to torpedo sales of its marquee product.

US tariffs are now standing at 145% on products made in China.

The Trump administration said late Friday it was excluding electronics, including smartphones, from the current reciprocal tariffs. But it still could levy new or different tariffs on electronics at a later date.

Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the US. He believes that moving production domestically likely couldn’t be done until, at the earliest, 2028.

Apple didn’t respond to a request for comment Wednesday. Apple CEO Tim Cook is scheduled to field questions from analysts during a quarterly conference call to discuss the company’s financial results and strategy on May 1.

Apple’s stock price has dropped by 15% and lowered the company’s market value by $500 billion since Trump began increasing tariffs on April 2.

Apple is widely expected to eventually raise the prices on iPhones and other popular products if the tariffs hold.

Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee said Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by the subscriptions and other services tied to its product. That division collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple’s last fiscal year.

Apple tried to appease Trump in February by announcing plans to spend $500 billion and hire 20,000 people in the US through 2028, but none of it was tied to making an iPhone domestically.

White House Press Secretary Karoline Levitt pointed to Apple’s investment promise as evidence that the company thinks it could be done.

US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a manufacturing shift during an April 6 appearance on a CBS news program.

During a 2017 appearance at a conference in China, Cook expressed doubt about whether the US labor pool had enough workers with the vocational skills required.

Trump also tried to pressure Apple, to no avail, into shifting iPhone production to the US during his first term as president. The administration ultimately exempted the iPhone from the tariffs he imposed on China back then. Apple had announced a commitment to invest $350 billion in the US.

Trump’s first-term tariffs on China also prompted Apple to begin a process that led to some of its current iPhones being made in India and some of its other products being manufactured in Vietnam.

Cook took the president on a 2019 tour of a Texas plant where Apple had been assembling some of its Mac computers since 2013.

El domingo, 13,7 millones de ecuatorianos decidirán el destino de su país.
Se enfrentan en una segunda vuelta presidencial Daniel Noboa Azín (de la coalición Acción Democrática Nacional) y Luisa González (de la Revolución Ciudadana, partido liderado por el expresidente Rafael Correa).

title: El shock tarifario de Trump obligará al Gobierno a recalcular - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: El impacto de la guerra comercial no será inocuo para la Argentina, que debe asegurarse cuanto antes el retorno a los mercados voluntarios de deuda ...
resumen:
El anuncio de Donald Trump de “aranceles recíprocos” el 2 de abril, comparado con los aranceles impuestos por los Estados Unidos en junio de 1930, llevaría el arancel a la importación promedio de los Estados Unidos de un 2,5% en promedio al 21% según un cálculo de Goldman Sachs, un banco de inversión, o incluso por encima del 25%.
El anuncio de Trump se basa en una fórmula para calcular el arancel a aplicar a cada país que se basa en el resultado comercial de dicho país con los Estados Unidos, incluyendo un parámetro de un paper escrito por Alberto Cavallo, Gita Gopinath, Brent Neiman y Jenny Tang.
Neiman sugirió en X (ex-Twiter) que un parámetro utilizado por el gobierno para la estimación de los aranceles recíprocos está mal, y que si se hubiese aplicado el correcto los aranceles recíprocos deberían ser de un cuarto de los aplicados.
El 9 de abril, el gobierno de Trump suspendió parte de los “aranceles recíprocos” durante 90 días, aplicando el 10% a todos los países excepto China.
El anuncio del 2 de abril implica un cambio paradigmático en la forma de organización del comercio y de la economía global.
La incertidumbre a la que están sometiendo a las empresas y a los mercados estas medidas llevarán a una fuerte desaceleración de la economía global, incluyendo muy probablemente a una recesión en los Estados Unidos.
El impacto directo de los “aranceles recíprocos” sobre Argentina no es tan elevado, aunque si afecta a algunos sectores importantes.
Las exportaciones a los Estados Unidos representan menos del 10% de las exportaciones totales, y menos del 1% del PBI.
Antes de las medidas de Trump, las exportaciones argentinas pagaban un arancel promedio del 1,6% en promedio.
Ahora estarán sujetas al 10% de arancel, con excepciones como el petróleo y los productos mineros, que no pagarán ningún arancel, y el aluminio, que pagará el 25%.
Las exportaciones agrícolas estarán gravadas al 10%.
Los efectos indirectos sobre la economía argentina son mucho más importantes.
La caída en el precio de los commodities, el petróleo cayó más de un 15%.
Eventos como este afectan el apetito por el riesgo de los inversores.
La suba del riesgo país de días recientes es parte de este fenómeno.
Argentina es un país sin reservas internacionales y sin acceso al mercado de deuda.
Estos eventos globales no serán inocuos para la Argentina.
Hacen más importante asegurar el retorno a los mercados voluntarios de deuda.
Se requiere apuntalar la acumulación de reservas internacionales, más allá de lo que nos presten el FMI y otros organismos de crédito.
Se requiere, en este contexto, un tipo de cambio más competitivo.

title: Trump eleva el tipo medio efectivo de los aranceles de EEUU a su nivel más alto en más de un siglo - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Las economías que se verán más afectadas por esta decisión son las asiáticas, algunas africanas y, entre las grandes, Corea del Sur, Japón, China e India. En Europa, tienen especial riesgo Alemania e ...
resumen: El 2 de abril, el presidente Donald Trump anunció un aumento de los derechos de aduanas para todos los socios comerciales de, al menos, un 10% y mucho más para determinados mercados. Esto elevaría el tipo efectivo medio de los aranceles estadounidenses al 26,2%, desde el 2,3% de 2024, alcanzando su nivel más alto en más de un siglo. La imposición de los llamados aranceles "recíprocos" de al menos el 10%, que entraron en vigor el sábado 5 de abril, marcan una escalada en la política comercial estadounidense. Muchos otros socios comerciales, como China (34%), la Unión Europea (20%) y Japón (24%), se enfrentarán a aranceles aún más elevados a partir del 9 de abril. México y Canadá son de los pocos países que escapan a estos impuestos "recíprocos" a la importación, conservando un acceso libre de aranceles al mercado estadounidense para los bienes que cumplan el acuerdo USMCA. La energía y los minerales no disponibles en el país, así como los sectores que ya están sujetos a derechos de aduana específicos (acero, aluminio, automoción) o que lo estarán en las próximas semanas, también estarán exentos. Las economías asiáticas (Vietnam, Camboya, Taiwán, Malasia y Tailandia) serán las más afectadas. Algunas economías africanas (Lesoto, Madagascar) y centroamericanas (Nicaragua, Honduras) también sentirán un impacto significativo. Entre las principales economías, es probable que Corea del Sur, Japón, China e India se vean muy afectadas. Todos los Estados miembros de la UE se enfrentarán a aranceles del 20%, con especial riesgo para Alemania e Italia. La economía estadounidense ya mostraba signos de debilitamiento. El aumento de los costes como consecuencia de la subida de los tipos de importación también podría frenar las decisiones de inversión de las empresas y de compra de los consumidores. El impacto sobre la inflación, que se prevé se sitúe en una media del 2,8% en 2025, será objeto de una atenta vigilancia. En 2024, los derechos de aduana generaron unos 88.000 millones de dólares, es decir, apenas el 1,5% de los ingresos federales totales.

El envío de más de 200 migrantes de Venezuela a la prisión salvadoreña busca disuadir a los migrantes de llegar a EE UU, como sucedió con los niños separados de sus padres en la frontera en 2018.
*   **La batalla por la nacionalidad de una profesora venezolana tras casi 40 años en España:** Estela Carmona logra la ciudadanía cuatro años después de que el Ministerio de Justicia se la negase porque no acreditó que habla español, su lengua materna, y que conoce los valores del país.

title: Análisis semanal: Momento bisagra - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: El Gobierno nacional anunció una profunda flexibilización del cepo y un cambio en el sistema cambiario que llegan a caballo de un nuevo préstamo del FMI. Es un paso arriesgado en un contexto difícil p ...
resumen:
El Gobierno nacional anunció una profunda flexibilización del cepo y un cambio en el sistema cambiario, a raíz de un nuevo préstamo del FMI. El Presidente celebró la medida como un hito histórico. Analistas destacan que la medida incentivará la llegada de inversiones pero podría generar una devaluación que alimente la inflación.

El presidente Javier Milei sorprendió con un cambio en las reglas de juego de la economía.

Se avanzó en una profunda flexibilización del cepo cambiario. Los individuos que quieran comprar dólar oficial podrán hacerlo desde el lunes sin mayores restricciones, aunque no queda claro cuántos dólares físicos podrán sacar de los bancos, además se eliminó el dólar blend. Se mantendrán los impuestos a las compras con tarjetas en el exterior y el dólar turista. Persisten las restricciones para empresas que pretendan pagar dividendos de ejercicios anteriores a 2025 y deudas acumuladas.

El desarme parcial del cepo llegó de la mano de un nuevo acuerdo con el FMI: Argentina recibirá 20 mil millones, 15 mil millones de los cuales llegarán este año junto a otros 8.000 millones prestados por otros organismos.

El Fondo exigió una modificación en la política cambiaria, que pasará de un tipo de cambio fijo a uno de flotación dentro de una banda con un límite superior de 1.400 pesos y uno inferior de 1.000. El Central no intervendrá mientras la cotización de la divisa se ubique en algún punto dentro de esos dos límites. Solo podrá vender dólares cuando su cotización se ubique por encima de los 1.400 pesos y comprará si baja de los 1.000 pesos.

El Central se reservó un margen de discrecionalidad para intervenir cuando detecte movimientos inusuales en el mercado aunque la cotización no exceda la banda.

El acuerdo con el FMI también incluye un compromiso de aumento de reservas.

La apertura del cepo mejora las condiciones del país para recibir inversiones, pero también agrega volatilidad.

En las últimas cuatro semanas el Central vendió más de 2.100 millones de dólares.

En marzo el IPC aumentó 3,7%.

La economía mundial está en pleno proceso de reconfiguración tras la escalada en la guerra comercial entre las dos mayores potencias.

El consenso de los analistas es que el nuevo sistema habilitará un salto devaluatorio de por lo menos 20 por ciento.

El Gobierno nacional cambió el eje central de su relato, que ya no gira en torno a la caída de la inflación sino a la eliminación del cepo.

El programa entre el Fondo Monetario Internacional, Banco Mundial, BID y un REPO del Banco Central asciende a 32.000 millones de dólares, de los cuales 19.600 millones serán desembolsados de manera inmediata. Para el mes de mayo las reservas brutas del Banco Central estarán en torno a los 50.000 millones.

El Gobierno estableció el techo de la banda en 1.400 pesos.

El respaldo de casi la totalidad de las cámaras empresariales a la flexibilización del cepo y la flotación sucia, se relaciona directamente con las expectativas de devaluación.

El cierre del mercado estadounidense para mercados exportadores como China y otros asiáticos resulta preocupante.

El Gobierno provincial establece condiciones razonables de previsibilidad en el plano político, mantiene la paz social y continúa invirtiendo para mejorar la infraestructura.

El próximo domingo se inaugurará el aeropuerto de El Soberbio.

El Parque de la Salud de Posadas incorporó un tomógrafo PET.

El Gobierno de Misiones se afirma en su identidad provincialista.

El Gobierno provincial podría haber especulado políticamente haciendo oposición destructiva, pero priorizó el bienestar colectivo y la coherencia.

El acompañamiento del Frente Renovador fue clave para sostener la institucionalidad.

title: Los aranceles rompen el amor de Wall Street por Donald Trump - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Desde Bill Ackman a Jamie Dimon o Ken Griffin, empresarios y banqueros de peso, muchos de ellos cercanos al movimiento MAGA, han roto el muro de silencio ante los severos efectos de los aranceles en l ...
resumen:
Wall Street ha perdido la ceguera con Donald Trump.

El Trump Trade, que disparó la Bolsa estadounidense en noviembre, se vio afectado por los aranceles.

En 2024, las promesas de desregulación y reducción de impuestos fueron bien recibidas por el mercado. El Trump Trade auguraba un dólar fuerte, una Bolsa alcista y subidas de los pequeños valores. El S&P 500 creció hasta un 7% entre octubre y diciembre.

La situación se torció en febrero, cuando el S&P alcanzó máximos. Primero llegó DeepSeek, luego Trump comenzó con escaramuzas arancelarias. La Bolsa pinchó y los analistas hablaron del Trump Put.

El 2 de abril, los mercados cayeron y surgió resistencia.

Bill Ackman, gestor de hedge funds y fundador de Pershing Square Capital Management, criticó los aranceles.

Cuando las Bolsas mundiales borraron más de nueve billones de euros de capitalización, Ackman y otros mostraron los dientes. Ackman publicó en X: “Estados Unidos se dirige hacia un invierno nuclear económico autoinducido”. Propuso una pausa de 90 días.

Ken Griffin, fundador de Citadel, criticó los gravámenes, calificándolos como un “grave error político”.

Larry Fink, CEO de BlackRock, dijo que el proteccionismo ha vuelto.

Stanley Druckenmiller escribió en X: “No apoyo aranceles superiores al 10%”.

Dan Loeb señaló que será una prueba del juicio racional de la administración.

Jamie Dimon, presidente de JP Morgan, reconoció que EE UU ha “permitido mucho comercio injusto”, pero advirtió que los aranceles aumentarían la inflación y la probabilidad de recesión.

Michael Cembalest, de JP Morgan, comentó que en Wall Street “hay temores de hablar en contra de la administración Trump”.

Hubo informes que pronosticaban más inflación (hasta el 5%) y una probable recesión.

El presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, avisó de las malas perspectivas.

El mercado de la deuda estadounidense estuvo a punto de romperse el 9 de abril.

Trump dio el brazo a torcer, pausando los aranceles por 90 días.

Fink (BlackRock) ha comparado el momento actual con la crisis financiera de 2008 y con la pandemia.

Dimon (JP Morgan) destaca que hay “turbulencias considerables” en la economía.

title: What to Know About Who Pays the Higher Costs of Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 12 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s trade policies will make imports more expensive and calculating and paying the tariffs more complicated.
resumen:
President Trump’s latest tariffs are about to become an unavoidable and expensive reality for American businesses and for people who rely on foreign goods.

Shoppers buying clothes from retailers in China may soon pay more than twice as much, now that a special exemption for lower-value imports is disappearing.

Companies involved in international trade must now make even more complicated calculations to decide how much they owe in tariffs.

Imports from China have been hit with tariffs of 145 percent. That means for every $100 worth of goods a business buys from that country, it has to pay $145 to the federal government.

Goods from most other countries have a new 10 percent tax, though that could rise if the countries do not reach trade agreements with the United States by July.

There are separate tariffs on cars, steel and aluminum.

Mr. Trump has also said he wants to impose new tariffs on pharmaceuticals and computer chips.

American businesses importing the goods pay the tariffs to the Customs and Border Protection when goods enter the United States.

Importers may pass some or all of the cost of the tariff to consumers through higher prices.

Most importers employ customs brokers who calculate the tariffs owed based on the goods’ value and where they were exported from.

Payments are made electronically, from the bank accounts of either importers or the brokers, who later recoup the money from their clients.

The tariffs end up at the Treasury Department.

Trade rules allow for some leeway. Importers who realize they have made a mistake and inform Customs and Border Protection are usually allowed to pay what they owe, plus interest.

Mr. Trump’s recent executive orders on metals tariffs were stricter than that. The order said Customs and Border Protection could impose much higher monetary penalties if importers misclassified goods.

Customs and Border Protection’s systems are already showing signs of strain.

On Friday, the agency said importers had not been able to submit tariffs owed on certain goods.

Customs and Border Protection said it was releasing the goods affected by this problem and allowing importers to submit their customs duties later.

Countries that don’t strike trade deals with the United States by July may face higher tariffs, and Mr. Trump may suddenly decide to introduce new tariffs.

U.S. imports from China totaled $439 billion last year.
