title: Trump's tariffs trigger recession alarm - (Published 12 hour(s), 31 minute(s) ago)
content: As stock markets remain volatile, investors are worried the global economy is on the verge of a slump. DW explores the impact of Trump's tariffs on US, Chinese and world growth.
resumen: Global stock markets have lost trillions of dollars in recent days. The rout on global financial markets continued for a third day on Monday (April 7) in reaction to US President Donald Trump's unprecedented tariffs on most trading partners of the United States. Investors are growing increasingly nervous about the prospect of a wider trade war, which would likely spark a global recession. The tariffs are poised to have far-reaching effects on world economic growth, due to much higher manufacturing costs, falling business confidence, market volatility and supply chain disruptions. Trump may have exacerbated further declines in Asia and Europe at the start of the week by saying that investors would have to deal with the market sell-off for now. JP Morgan said last week it believes the odds of a global recession are now at 60% by the end of the year, compared to 40% before Trump's vast array of tariffs was announced. Deutsche Bank warned in a research note Monday that as Trump doubles down, the new tariffs would have "immense global implications for 2025 and the years and decades ahead." Asia was hit much harder than Europe with levies of more than 40% on some key countries, prompting the likes of Vietnam, Taiwan and Indonesia on Sunday to seek new trade deals with Washington. China is the only major economy to order retaliatory tariffs on US imports following last Wednesday's announcement. Beijing ordered extra levies of 34% on American goods and put export curbs on some rare earths. Those tariffs are due to take effect this Thursday. Having hit China with an additional 34% tariff last week, Trump doubled down on Monday, threatening an additional 50% tariff if Beijing doesn't withdraw its latest tariff increase. India, which now faces a 26% levy on exports to the US, does not plan to retaliate against Trump's tariffs, Reuters news agency reported Sunday, citing an unnamed Indian official. Imports from the European Union to the US face levies of 20% starting Wednesday. EU finance ministers met in Luxembourg on Monday to agree on around €26 billion ($28.46 billion) of new levies in response to Trump's earlier 25% tariffs on aluminum and steel. Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, the bloc's executive arm, said Sunday that Brussels was prepared to "defend its interests with proportionate countermeasures." ABN Amro, one of the largest Dutch banks, last week halved its economic outlook for EU member states, saying it expects the bloc's quarterly growth to "hover around zero, with a high chance of a negative quarter." More than 50 countries had been in touch to seek new trade deals with Washington. Paul Ashworth from Capital Economics said that despite the US president's defiant rhetoric, Trump would soon realize that he'd gone too far. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon wrote in an annual letter to shareholders that "the quicker this issue is resolved, the better because some of the negative effects increase cumulatively over time and would be hard to reverse." The US economy has averaged nearly 3% growth since the end of the COVID-19 pandemic but now faces what research house Morningstar called a "self-inflicted economic catastrophe" as a result of Trump's tariffs. S&P Global raised its probability of a US recession to between 30% and 35%, up from 25% in March. Goldman Sachs increased the chances of a US recession in the next year to 45%, while Barclays and UBS also warned that the US economy may contract in the next few months. Steve Cochrane, chief Asia-Pacific economist at Moody's Analytics warned Monday that the US could fall into recession "very quickly" and that it could be "rather lengthy." Capital Economics warned that if Trump is unwilling to make deals with US trade partners, the stock market rout would soon be followed by a "collapse in household and business confidence." The UK-based economic research house warned that US inflation could rise above 5% and that the recession would worsen if the US Congress "fails to pass timely fiscal stimulus because of Republican infighting." US Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell last week warned the tariffs would likely cause US inflation to rise and growth to slow. Markets are now betting that Federal Reserve Chair Powell will soon announce US rate cuts earlier than previously expected. Trump's tariffs are widely expected to hinder China's economy, by disrupting export activities and causing substantial market volatility. Beijing is expected to implement monetary and fiscal measures to offset the additional tariff and the People's Daily, the Communist Party's mouthpiece newspaper, tried to reassure Chinese readers that "the sky won't fall... even if the US tariffs have an impact." China's Foreign Ministry on Monday criticized Trump's tariffs as "economic bullying" and "inconsistent with international trade rules," urging the US to resolve trade tensions in a mutually beneficial way. Goldman Sachs said in a report Sunday that it had planned to upgrade its growth forecast for China before Trump's tariffs were announced. Goldman said the new levies would lower Chinese GDP growth by at least 0.7 percentage points this year. Kaiyuan Securities said it expects the tariffs could slash Chinese exports to the US by almost a third, cut overall exports by more than 4.5%, and drag economic growth by 1.3 percentage points. Cochrane from Moody's Analytics warned that China would certainly feel economic pain "because demand for its goods will be hit even harder [than the US]." Deutsche Bank noted how China has gone from manufacturing 5% of global goods to 32% in thirty years while US-produced goods have fallen by more than a third to 15%. The US exported $144.6 billion (€132 billion) in goods to China in 2024, much less than the $439.7 billion it imported, China's Commerce Department data showed.

title: Markets calmer despite growing US-China trade tensions - (Published 14 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: Stock markets regained some ground on Tuesday, even as trade tensions between the United States and China escalated sharply after days of turmoil over US President Donald Trump's tariffs ...
resumen:
Stock markets regained some ground on Tuesday, even as trade tensions between the United States and China escalated sharply after days of turmoil over US President Donald Trump's tariffs offensive.

Trump has upended the world economy with sweeping tariffs that have raised the spectre of an international recession, but has ruled out any pause in his aggressive trade policy despite a dramatic market sell-off.

Steep tariffs come into effect against goods from a raft of nations on Wednesday, with Chinese products facing a 34-percent levy that Beijing will counter with a similar duty on Thursday.

Trump has warned he would impose additional levies of 50 percent if Beijing refused to stop pushing back against his tariffs.

"I have great respect for China but they can not do this," Trump said at the White House.

China swiftly hit back, blasting what it called "blackmailing" by the United States and vowing "countermeasures" if Washington imposes more tariffs.

"If the US insists on going its own way, China will fight it to the end," a spokesperson for Beijing's commerce ministry said on Tuesday.

China's foreign ministry also condemned "ignorant and impolite" remarks by US Vice President JD Vance in which he complained the United States had for too long borrowed money from "Chinese peasants".

The ministry said that "pressure, threats and blackmail are not the right way to deal with China".

The European Union sought to cool tensions, with the bloc's chief Ursula von der Leyen warning against worsening the trade conflict in a call with Chinese Premier Li Qiang.

She stressed the "vital importance of stability" for the world's economy as well as "the need to avoid further escalation," according to a readout from EU officials.

The Chinese premier told von der Leyen that the world's number two economy has the "tools" necessary to weather economic headwinds.

"China can fully hedge against adverse external effects, and is fully confident of maintaining sustained and healthy economic development," he said, according to state news agency Xinhua.

The EU said Tuesday that it expects to present as soon as next week its response to the 20-percent levies it is facing under Trump's latest tariff wave, with Germany and France advocating a tax targeting US tech giants.

Brussels has also proposed an exemption from tariffs on industrial products, including cars, which Trump said was not enough to resolve the US trade deficit with the EU.

"The European Union has been very, very bad to us," Trump said.

In retaliation for US levies introduced in mid-March on steel and aluminium, the EU plans tariffs of up to 25 percent on US goods ranging from soybeans to motorcycles and make-up, according to a document seen by AFP.

A 10 percent "baseline" tariff on US imports from around the world took effect Saturday.

Trump's tariffs have roiled global markets, with trillions of dollars wiped off combined stock market valuations in recent sessions.

Wall Street stocks surged at the open Tuesday, with all three major US indices up more than three percent as Trump reported a "great call" with South Korea's leader while US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Japan had sought quick negotiations.

Europe's main stock markets were up around three percent in afternoon trade while Asia's leading indices also rose after suffering particularly heavy falls on Monday.

Trump believes the tariffs will revive America's lost manufacturing base by forcing foreign companies to relocate to the United States, rather than making goods abroad.

Despite the turmoil, Trump said Monday he was "not looking" at any pause in tariff implementation.

He also scrapped any meetings with China but said Washington was ready for talks with any country willing to negotiate. More than 50 nations have sought reach out to the US leader, according to the White House.

While meeting Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the first leader to lobby Trump in person over the levies, Trump said: "There can be permanent tariffs, and there can also be negotiations, because there are things that we need beyond tariffs."

title: As China and the US spar, countries brainstorm over how to cope with the trade war - (Published 8 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: Governments are brainstorming over strategies for coping with the trade war between the world’s top economies.
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump and China sparred over tariff hikes and other retaliatory moves on Tuesday, as governments elsewhere were brainstorming strategies to cope with the trade war between the global economic giants. China said it will “fight to the end” and take countermeasures against the United States to safeguard its own interests after President Donald Trump threatened an additional 50% tariff on Chinese imports in retaliation for Beijing’s backlash against the 34% tariffs he ordered on his April 2 “Liberation Day.” The Commerce Ministry said in a statement read on state-run broadcaster CCTV that the U.S. threat to escalate tariffs on China is a mistake and exposes the blackmailing nature of the US, and that China will never accept this. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said that the U.S. actions don’t reflect a willingness for sincere dialogue and that if the US really wants to engage in dialogue, it should adopt an attitude of equality, mutual respect and mutual benefit. Chinese state-run companies were told to help support the country’s financial markets after they were hit by massive saves of selling on Monday. Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba spoke with Trump late Monday and then convened a task force Tuesday to mitigate damage from the 24% U.S. tariffs imposed on Washington’s biggest ally in Asia. Economic Revitalization Minister Ryosei Akazawa was appointed lead trade negotiator and senior officials were dispatched to Washington to follow up on the Ishiba’s talk with Trump. Ishiba told his ministers to do their utmost to get Trump to reconsider and also to mitigate the impact from the U.S. “reciprocal” tariffs. India’s Foreign Minister S. Jaishankar spoke with his U.S. counterpart Marco Rubio late Monday, pitching for an early conclusion of negotiations for a bilateral trade agreement. India, which faces a 26% tariff on its exports to the U.S., is hoping for concessions as part of the trade deal. A first tranche of the agreement is expected by this fall. Washington wants India to allow more open market access for U.S. dairy and other farm products. India’s Trade Minister Piyush Goyal planned to meet with exporters Wednesday to gauge the potential impact and cushion the economy from the tariffs. A State Department statement said Rubio and Jaishankar discussed ways to deepen collaboration, the tariffs and “how to make progress toward a fair and balanced trade relationship.” Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said his government and other Southeast Asian countries would send officials to Washington to discuss the tariffs and it was working to build a consensus on a unified response among the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations as they convened an investment conference in Kuala Lumpur. Anwar said Malaysia would stick to a policy of diversifying its trade at a time of uncertainty over globalization and changing supply chains. Hong Kong’s Chief Executive John Lee echoed Beijing in blasting Trump’s tariffs as “bullying” and “ruthless behavior” he said had damaged trade and raised global uncertainty. Lee said the former British colony would draw closer to the Chinese mainland, sign more free trade agreements and strive to attract more foreign investment to help blunt the impact of the higher U.S. duties.

title: Bill Ackman defends Trump tariffs after warning the world was on brink of ‘economic nuclear winter,’ attacking Commerce secretary - (Published 7 hour(s), 14 minute(s) ago)
content: The hedge fund manager, one of Trump’s most notable business allies during his campaign, doubled down on his call for the president to institute a 90-day pause on the tariffs.
resumen: Billionaire fund manager Bill Ackman reaffirmed his support for President Trump’s trade policy, saying some had “misinterpreted” his call for a 90-day pause on reciprocal tariffs as a criticism of the administration. The Pershing Square Capital Management boss had warned on Sunday that the world is on the brink of “self-induced economic nuclear winter” if the harsher tariffs slated to kick in tomorrow are not delayed. Ackman wrote Tuesday on X, adding that he is “totally supportive” of President Trump’s use of tariffs. Ackman is advocating for a 30, 60, or 90- day pause before the tariffs are implemented to enable negotiations to be completed without a major global economic disruption that will harm the most vulnerable companies and citizens of our country. If nations don’t step up to the negotiating table, then Trump “can bring the hammer down, but doing so without giving time to make deals creates unnecessary harm,” he continued. Shares in Ackman’s main fund plunged about 3.5% on Monday. The stock bounced back by nearly 3% on Tuesday. In his long post on X on Sunday, Ackman wrote: “If…on April 9th we launch economic nuclear war on every country in the world, business investment will grind to a halt, consumers will close their wallets and pocket books, and we will severely damage our reputation with the rest of the world that will take years and potentially decades to rehabilitate,” Ackman. Ackman, who voted for Trump in the election, added that he has “a lot of respect for our president,” but does not believe Trump is infallible and that it would be a mistake to move forward with the taxes on Wednesday. Many of Ackman’s largest investments, like Nike, Mexican fast-food chain Chipotle, investment firm Brookfield and Alphabet, suffered major losses during the multi-day rout as investors worried Trump’s new tariffs could stoke inflation or even trigger a recession. Google-parent Alphabet and Brookfield were two of Ackman’s biggest positions in the trust at the end of last year, worth about $2 billion and $1.8 billion, respectively, according to The Financial Times. Shares in Nike, for example, plummeted over concerns it could be forced to hike its sneaker prices, since it relies heavily on Vietnam for manufacturing, and the Southeast Asian nation is staring down a 46% levy. Ackman had also taken aim at Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, the former chief executive and chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, in his Sunday missive on X. Ackman wrote in a post on X, calling Lutnick’s firm an “irreconcilable conflict of interest.” Ackman then reversed course, saying it was “unfair” of him to “lash out” at Lutnick. Ackman wrote in another post on X: “I don’t think he is pursuing his self interest. I am sure he is doing the best he can for the country.” Ackman continued: “I am just frustrated watching what I believe to be a major policy error occur after our country and the president have been making huge economic progress that is now at risk due to the tariffs.” Dan Loeb also spoke out against the levies. Shares in his firm Third Point had fallen nearly 10% as of Monday.

title: Trump Tariffs May Rewire Market Psychology - (Published 13 hour(s), 5 minute(s) ago)
content: Trade tensions have begun to force a rethink about how much investors and businesses should bet on the United States.
resumen:
Global markets are rebounding on Tuesday even as trade tensions show little signs of cooling. Beijing vowed that it “will fight to the end” against President Trump’s latest tariff threats. Wall Street analysts have issued a flurry of downgrades for the S&P 500, and billionaire business leaders are pushing back against Trump, including Elon Musk, who directly appealed to Trump to reverse course. C.E.O.s and investors worry that an irreversible new era for global business is at hand. Trump’s sweeping tariffs won’t just dent global growth, but will also trigger a new era of protectionist policies that drive up inflation, sap corporate profits and chill investment — especially in the United States. Joachim Klement, the head of strategy at the investment bank Panmure Liberum, told DealBook that this “can’t put the toothpaste back in the tube moment” is real. Fund managers from around the world poured into U.S. stocks, a lucrative trade nicknamed “TINA,” short for “there is no alternative.” That trade has reversed dramatically since Election Day, with stocks in Asia and Europe outperforming their American counterparts. Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase warned on Monday that stock prices “remain relatively high.” The greenback’s slump against other currencies has floored many on Wall Street, as did Monday’s sell-off in Treasury bonds. Henry Allen, a markets strategist at Deutsche Bank, wrote in a research note on Tuesday that it “spoke to broader concerns about the safety of U.S. assets and their capacity to act as a haven in times of market stress.” A pension fund in Denmark has begun to shed its holdings in U.S. tech giants. Wei Li, BlackRock’s global chief investment strategist, told Bloomberg Television on Tuesday that the coming days could test investors’ mettle. Peter Navarro, a key White House trade adviser, argues in The Financial Times that the point of Trump’s tariffs is to “fix a broken system” of international trade — and adds, “This is not a negotiation.”

A key business trade group reportedly weighs suing to block Trump tariffs. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is considering whether to take the Trump administration to court to forestall levies set to take effect tomorrow, Fortune reports. Apple is said to be working on an iPhone tariff workaround. The tech giant plans to ship more iPhones to the U.S. from India as a short-term way to offset the newly vertiginous levies on goods from China, according to The Wall Street Journal. (Chinese goods currently face a 54 percent duty, while Indian ones are subject to 26 percent.) UBS analysts estimated that the price of iPhones in the U.S. could rise by as much as $350 because of tariffs. The Panamanian government’s top auditor said that a subsidiary of CK Hutchison, the Hong Kong owner of the two ports, owes about $300 million in contractual payments and didn’t receive certain required approvals. George Tenet is leaving Allen & Company. Tenet, who led the intelligence agency from 1996 to 2004, had been chairman of the well-connected media-focused investment bank for more than a decade. He will become executive chairman of CHAOS Industries a defense tech start-up co-founded by his son, John, DealBook is first to report.

Talks toward an agreement to separate TikTok from its Chinese owner, ByteDance, came to a standstill when ByteDance called the White House to inform it that the Chinese government would not let a TikTok deal proceed, Lauren Hirsch, David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari reported for The Times. The stated reason: President Trump’s new tariffs on Chinese goods. The proposed deal would allow TikTok’s biggest American backers, including General Atlantic and Susquehanna International Group, to hold onto their investments while government officials brought in new funds to dilute the app’s Chinese ownership. New investors would own 50 percent of a new American TikTok entity, while Chinese owners would retain less than 20 percent. An escalating trade war may only make talks harder. Trump has repeatedly suggested that he would consider lowering tariffs on China in exchange for its approval of a TikTok deal. The tariff fight may still be raging when a 75-day extension for the TikTok talks, which Trump approved on Friday, expires in June. Anupam Chander, a professor of law and technology at Georgetown University, told The Times, “We may well find ourselves back in Groundhog Day.”

Ken Langone, the investor and early backer of Home Depot, said, “Forty-six per cent on Vietnam? Come on! … You might as well tell them, ‘Don’t even bother calling.’” Ken Griffin, the billionaire financier and Republican mega-donor, called the tariffs a “huge policy mistake.” Larry Fink, the C.E.O. of BlackRock, said that “the economy is weakening as we speak.” Dan Loeb responded to an X post by the economist Nouriel Roubini criticizing fellow hedge fund mogul Bill Ackman for initially praising Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, then attacking him for his support for tariffs.

For about a half-hour on Monday, the stock market went frenetic. The S&P 500, which had been sliding for days in reaction to President Trump’s tariff plan, suddenly spiked, surging more than 3 percent. Altogether, more than $6 trillion traded hands in 30 minutes, according to one estimate. Traders appeared to be reacting to a post on X that said Trump was open to a 90-day pause on the tariffs, attributed to Kevin Hassett, the director of the National Economic Council. At 10:13 a.m. ET, a post from the pseudonymous X account Walter Bloomberg read: “HASSETT: TRUMP IS CONSIDERING A 90-DAY PAUSE IN TARIFFS FOR ALL COUNTRIES EXCEPT CHINA.” The CNBC anchor Carl Quintanilla cited the headline on air. His guest, the economist Jeremy Siegel, said, “That’s huge. I mean that changes the game.” At 10:19 a.m., Reuters flashed the same headline, citing CNBC. The White House quickly called reports about a tariff pause “Fake News” on X. The person behind Walter Bloomberg told The Times’s Benjamin Mullin he first spotted the headline on a different X account, which had posted two minutes earlier. CNBC, which circulated the incorrect news, later issued a correction, as did Reuters.

President Trump ordered a new national security review into Nippon Steel’s nearly $15 billion takeover of U.S. Steel. PNC Financial hired Mark Wiedman, the former senior BlackRock executive as its president. New payment-rate increases by the Trump administration for private Medicare insurers could generate more than $25 billion in additional revenue for the industry. Mike Bloomberg’s gun control group plans to spend $10 million to help elect Democratic attorneys general this year and next. The C.E.O. of Shopify, the e-commerce platform, told employees they need to show that jobs can’t be performed by artificial intelligence before they can hire people to fill them.

Hasset explicó que "no sería apropiado" introducir un nuevo elemento en las negociaciones en medio del proceso, sobre todo teniendo en cuenta que estas negociaciones "afectan a miles de vidas".

El pasado miércoles Trump anunció los aranceles "recíprocos" sobre sus principales socios comerciales, pero llamó la atención la ausencia de países como Rusia, Bielorrusia, Cuba o Corea del Norte.

La Casa Blanca explicó que estos países ya tienen sanciones en vigor.

Hasset destacó que más de 50 países, incluida Rusia, se han puesto ya en contacto con Washington para negociar exenciones a los aranceles.

Funcionarios de EEUU dicen que esas naciones "ya enfrentan aranceles extremadamente altos" que "impiden cualquier comercio significativo con estos países".

Hasset aseguró que hay más de 50 países que se han puesto en contacto con el presidente para abrir una negociación.

Hasset descartó un impacto significativo en los consumidores estadounidenses.

Desde la propia Administración han reconocido que va a haber un incremento de los precios e incluso Trump ha mencionado una estrategia deliberada para obligar a la Reserva Federal a bajar los tipos de interés.

title: China avisa que irá “hasta el final” con los aranceles de Trump - (Published 7 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: PEKÍN. China, la segunda mayor economía del mundo, avisa que irá “hasta el final” para hacer frente a la política arancelaria de Estados Unidos e impuesta por el presidente Donald Trump.
resumen:
China, la segunda mayor economía del mundo, avisa que irá “hasta el final” para hacer frente a la política arancelaria de Estados Unidos e impuesta por el presidente Donald Trump.
China prometió combatir los aranceles de Estados Unidos “hasta el final” después de que el presidente Donald Trump amenazara con gravámenes suplementarios, una nueva escalada en la guerra comercial entre las dos principales economías mundiales.
China, el principal rival económico de Washington pero también un socio comercial clave, respondió al anuncio de aranceles de la semana pasada anunciando a su vez gravámenes del 34% sobre los productos estadounidenses a partir de mañana.
Trump replicó con la amenaza de nuevos aranceles, que llevaría los gravámenes de Estados Unidos sobre los productos chinos a un total del 104%.
China respondió denunciando las “presiones, amenazas y chantajes” de Estados Unidos, en palabras del portavoz del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, Lin Jian.
Un portavoz del Ministerio de Comercio advirtió que “la amenaza de Estados Unidos de aumentar los aranceles contra China es un error tras otro y expone una vez más la naturaleza chantajista de Estados Unidos”.
“Estados Unidos insiste en seguir su propio camino, China luchará hasta el final”, agregó, explicando que el gigante asiático tomará “contramedidas” para defender sus “derechos e intereses”, aunque al mismo tiempo pidió “diálogo”.
El portavoz del Ministerio de Exteriores chino, Lin Jian.
Trump asegura que la economía de Estados Unidos ha sido “saqueada” durante años por el resto del mundo.
La semana pasada anunció un arancel general del 10% a todos los productos importados, al que se añaden gravámenes específicos por países, entre ellos los de la Unión Europea (20%) o Vietnam (46%) que deberían entrar en vigor el miércoles.
Según el Secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, los aranceles aduaneros anunciados el 2 de abril servirán para poner a Estados Unidos en una posición de fortaleza, dijo en declaraciones a Fox News.

title: Zovatto: la Celac llega fragmentada a su IX Cumbre y sin una estrategia común ante Trump - (Published 23 hour(s), 57 minute(s) ago)
content: Redacción América – La Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac) celebrará este miércoles 9 de abril su IX Cumbre en Tegucigalpa en un contexto regional marcado por la fragmentación, l ...
resumen:
La Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac) celebrará el miércoles 9 de abril su IX Cumbre en Tegucigalpa.

El jurista y politólogo argentino Daniel Zovatto advierte que la región llega profundamente desarticulada a este encuentro.

Asistirán, entre otros mandatarios, Gustavo Petro, de Colombia; Luis Arce, de Bolivia; Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, de Brasil; Miguel Díaz-Canel, de Cuba; Yamandú Orsi, de Uruguay; Claudia Sheinbaum, de México; Bernardo Arévalo, de Guatemala, y Leslie Voltaire, mandatario provisional de Haití, además de la anfitriona, Xiomara Castro.

Zovatto cuestiona la viabilidad de una posición unificada frente a temas como la guerra comercial impulsada por Donald Trump o el papel de China en la región.

Zovatto, investigador senior en el Centro de Estudios Internacionales de la Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, remarca que la heterogeneidad de sus miembros y la disparidad en los niveles de representación pueden dificultar cualquier avance sustantivo.

El evento se perfila como una reunión de «tres pisos»: uno bilateral con Estados Unidos, otro simbólico y un tercero retórico.

Zovatto expresa escepticismo sobre la posibilidad de que la región actúe de forma coordinada frente a la política comercial agresiva de Trump.

Muchos Gobiernos respiraron aliviados por haber recibido un “castigo menor” que otros ante las recientes sanciones arancelarias.

La mayoría de los países optarán por negociar bilateralmente con Washington, en lugar de adoptar una estrategia regional conjunta.

La economía de México depende en un 83 % de las exportaciones a Estados Unidos.

Es imposible establecer una postura común sobre la relación con China cuando los vínculos económicos con el gigante asiático son tan dispares.

Zovatto valora iniciativas simbólicas como la propuesta del brasileño Lula da Silva de presentar un candidato latinoamericano único para la Secretaría General de la ONU.

La Cumbre de Tegucigalpa tendrá lugar el mismo día en que entra en vigor el segundo tramo de los “aranceles recíprocos”, que comprende las tasas superiores al 10 % a las importaciones procedentes de terceros países.

Zovatto concluye que la región se ha ido desintegrando cada vez más.

title: The extremely flawed logic behind Trump’s chaotic trade war - (Published 14 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump often champions major corporate investments as evidence that his economic agenda is starting to work.
resumen: President Donald Trump often champions major corporate investments as evidence that his economic agenda is starting to work. But his chaotic policymaking could have the opposite effect: It could paralyze businesses. Markets are melting down, trade war turbulence is off the charts, and consumer confidence is plunging. John Graham, finance professor at Duke University, said, “Without a doubt, this could freeze things rather than spur investment.” James Bullard, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, told CNBC on Monday that there is a growing risk of a repeat of the Smoot-Hawley Act, the infamous 1930 tariff hike that worsened the Great Depression. Mary Lovely, senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said companies will struggle to invest if they don’t know how enduring tariffs are. Bill Ackman, the hedge fund billionaire who endorsed Trump last election, warned that “business investment will grind to a halt” if the president doesn’t pause the tariffs. Ackman said, “By placing massive and disproportionate tariffs on our friends and our enemies alike and thereby launching a global economic war against the whole world at once, we are in the process of destroying confidence in our country as a trading partner, as a place to do business, and as a market to invest capital.” The tariff threats have made it almost impossible for businesses to plan. Lovely said it’s “anyone’s guess what the value of the dollar is going to be tomorrow, let alone 10 weeks from now.” Trump’s trade war has led CEOs and investment banks to warn of a potential recession. One oil executive told the Dallas Fed in a survey released last month, “The administration’s chaos is a disaster for the commodity markets. ‘Drill, baby, drill’ is nothing short of a myth and populist rallying cry. Tariff policy is impossible for us to predict and doesn’t have a clear goal. We want more stability.”

title: Markets Slide Again in Afternoon Slump as Trade Tensions Escalate - (Published Apr 8, 2025)
content: An early rally on Wall Street faded and the S&P 500 ended the day down 1.6 percent after the White House reaffirmed plans to impose high tariffs on China and other countries at midnight.
resumen: Stocks around the world recouped some losses caused by President Trump’s tariffs, but an early Wall Street rally faded by the afternoon on April 7, 2025. The S&P 500 opened with a big gain but wavered, remaining nearly 18 percent below its mid-February record after tumbling more than 10 percent since Mr. Trump announced tariffs on major U.S. partners last week. Investors took solace in signs that Washington may be open for negotiations on tariffs after Mr. Trump spoke with the acting president of South Korea. Mr. Trump’s announcement of a 10 percent base tax on American imports and higher rates on goods from dozens of other countries, set to take effect on Wednesday, had unsettled markets. Countries have responded with tariffs of their own. China retaliated on Friday, matching a new 34 percent tariff with one of its own on many American imports. Before markets opened in China on Tuesday, the government unleashed measures to stabilize stocks, causing share prices in Hong Kong and mainland China to jump about 1.5 percent. Stocks in Japan gained 6 percent. Markets in Taiwan continued to drop, and the finance ministry said it would activate a $15 billion stabilization fund. The Stoxx Europe 600 gained 2.7 percent. Euronext's chief executive, Stéphane Boujnah, said the disruption caused by tariffs had made the U.S. markets “unrecognizable” to investors, who were shifting some of their money to Europe from the United States. Business leaders and analysts are worried that escalating trade tensions could damage the global economy, with some economists forecasting a recession later this year. Citigroup's chief executive, Jane Fraser, said conversations in Washington and Mexico are centered on the urgency of the moment and that "we should prepare for a fundamental shift in trade and capital flows.” A survey of small businesses in the United States recorded a decline in confidence for a third straight month. Brent crude continued to slide on Tuesday, trading at around $63 a barrel. The 10.5 percent drop in the S&P 500 on Thursday and Friday was the worst two-day decline since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020. On Monday, Mr. Trump issued a new ultimatum to China to rescind its retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods, or face additional tariffs of 50 percent beginning Wednesday. Treasury secretary Scott Bessent said China was making “a big mistake.” Several Chinese government departments and government-owned enterprises pledged to “maintain the smooth operation of the capital market.” The People’s Bank of China vowed to support Central Huijin Investment, which said it was increasing its holdings of stock funds. Dozens of companies announced that they were buying back some of their shares. Mr. Trump’s tariffs could inflict damage on China’s economy.

title: Trump trade official signals tariffs are negotiating tool amid GOP skepticism - (Published Apr 8, 2025)
content: Trump's trade representative Jamieson Greer told Senators that President Trump's tariffs prompted more than 50 countries to reach out to negotiate trade deals. But Greer declined to give a timeline.
resumen: U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer testified before the Senate Finance Committee on April 8, 2025, regarding President Trump's 2025 trade policy agenda, stating the goal of the sweeping tariffs is to negotiate new trade deals. Greer said roughly 50 countries reached out to talk with the administration instead of retaliating, suggesting Trump's approach is working. Greer assured lawmakers that the goal was to incentivize negotiations, pointing to examples of countries like Vietnam and India reaching out. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said almost 70 countries have reached out since Trump's tariff announcement last week and that Trump directed his trade team to create "tailor-made trade deals" with countries seeking tariff cuts. Greer stated that Trump's plans to impose new tariffs on China would go forward as scheduled for midnight, with tariffs set to rise to at least 104% on Wednesday. Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon announced he was introducing a bipartisan privileged resolution that would terminate the national emergency Trump invoked to impose his tariffs, with Republican Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky also joining the effort. Sen. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, has introduced legislation to claw back congressional power over international trade and tariffs. Republican Sen. James Lankford of Oklahoma pressed Greer for a timeline for the tariffs, but Greer declined to specify any target date. Republican Sen. Ron Johnson of Wisconsin expressed disappointment that exclusions for some companies "are being ruled out right now." Sen. Thom Tillis of North Carolina admitted that the Trump administration faced a tight window of roughly 14 months for these policies to demonstrate they were working. Sen. Todd Young, R-Ind., asked Greer to factor in that trade retaliation doesn't fall on everyone evenly. Senate Majority Leader John Thune, R-S.D., noted that Trump ran on the issue in 2024 and deserves the opportunity to see what kind of deals he can get from some of our trading partners.

title: Paraguay escapa del colapso global pero hay preocupación por el impacto de la crisis en Taiwan - (Published 22 hour(s), 0 minute(s) ago)
content: La falta de integración en los mercados globales y la estabilidad marcroeconómica blindan al país de un efecto mayor en la guerra comercial.
resumen:
Las principales bolsas del mundo enfrentan una fuerte crisis global con caídas estrepitosas en Asia, Europa y Estados Unidos.
Los analistas hablan de un "Lunes negro" que puede tener impacto en los precios de algunos commodities como la soja y el combustible, de gran relevancia para Paraguay.
Tokio suspendió operaciones tras un desplome del 7,8%, seguido por Hong Kong (-13,22%) y Shanghái (-7,34%).
Los mercados occidentales anticiparon un "lunes negro" con pre-aperturas en rojo y escenas de compras de pánico en Estados Unidos, donde se teme una recesión global con epicentro en la primera economía mundial.
La angustia se extiende a Latinoamérica, donde el fantasma de la inflación, la pérdida de empleos y la volatilidad cambiaria preocupan a los gobiernos.
En ese marco de inestabilidad total, el país parece escapar al colapso financiero.
Analistas locales destacan que el impacto directo es limitado, dado el bajo nivel de integración de su bolsa con los mercados globales.
Sin embargo, la caída de commodities como la soja -producto clave para Paraguay- podría afectar ingresos.
El BCP estima que el tipo de cambio se estabilizará antes de mitad de año y desmiente la fuga de dólares a Bolivia.
Los precios ya retroceden por la expectativa de menor demanda en un escenario recesivo.
Julieta Heduvan, especialista en relaciones internacionales, advirtió que el efecto más visible sería en los commodities.
Peña y el presidente taiwanés Lai Ching-te.
"No necesariamente en las ventas a Taiwán, que opera con cupos y no bajo reglas de libre mercado", añadió haciendo referencia a uno de los principales socios de Paraguay, cuya bolsa de Taipéi tiene un desplome cercano al 10%.
El crudo se hundió a menos de US$ 60 por barril, una noticia ambivalente para la región.
Mientras países importadores como Paraguay podrían ahorrar en energía, los exportadores sudamericanos (Ecuador, Colombia) enfrentan presión fiscal.
Además, la ralentización de economías compradoras de materias primas, como China, podría reducir flujos comerciales hacia el Mercosur.
Heduvan señala que Taiwán -socio clave de Paraguay- prioriza negociar con Estados Unidos para evitar represalias arancelarias, lo que podría desviar capitales hacia el norte.
"Habría que ver qué enfoque tiene Trump sobre su política con Taiwán, eso todavía no está bien definido", aseguró.
De incrementar inversiones en el norte, los recursos para trasladar inversiones a Paraguay disminuirán.
Lo que sí es objetivo y seguro es que la volatilidad global suele presionar el tipo de cambio en Sudamérica, pero Paraguay cuenta con reservas sólidas y un sistema financiero resiliente.
El Banco Central viene interviniendo el mercado con US$ 15 millones por día para que el dólar no supere la barrera de los G. 8.000 y afecte a las compras de insumos y otras importaciones.
Globalmente, la incertidumbre domina.
Si los aranceles de Trump se mantienen, JP Morgan prevé una recesión en Estados Unidos para el segundo semestre, lo que agravaría la caída de commodities y el crédito internacional.
Paraguay, aunque blindado en lo inmediato, no es inmune a un shock prolongado.
Carlos Fernández Valdovinos, ministro de Economía.

title: Francia ratifica su posición contra el acuerdo UE-Mercosur - (Published 8 hour(s), 3 minute(s) ago)
content: PARÍS. Francia ratifica su posición contra el acuerdo de asociación comercial entre la Unión Europea y el Mercosur, y enfatiza que “noes un remedio” a las tarifas impuestas por Estados Unidos.
resumen:
Francia ratifica su posición contra el acuerdo de asociación comercial entre la Unión Europea y el Mercosur.

La ministra francesa de Agricultura, Annie Genevard, declaró que el acuerdo comercial entre la Unión Europea y el Mercosur “no es un remedio” a los aranceles de Donald Trump, ya que “agregaría más desorden”.

Francia lidera un grupo de países europeos que se oponen a la ratificación del acuerdo negociado en diciembre entre la Comisión Europea y Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay, que crearía un mercado de 700 millones de personas.

Genevard dijo que el Mercosur “era malo ayer y sigue siéndolo, en mi opinión, para los cruciales sectores agrícola y agroalimentario de nuestro país”.

De ratificarse, la UE, primer socio comercial del Mercosur, podría exportar más fácilmente autos, maquinaria y productos farmacéuticos, mientras que el bloque sudamericano podría exportar a Europa más carne, azúcar, soja, miel, etc.

Francia reclama que las exportaciones del bloque sudamericano cumplan las mismas normas de producción que la UE.

Genevard agregó que el acuerdo “favorecería otras producciones francesas y en especial la producción vitícola, pero un buen acuerdo es uno equilibrado”, para quien los sectores más impactados serían los de la carne ovina y bovina, del azúcar y el etanol.

Genevard consideró que el Mercosur “no es un remedio”, sí calificó de “buena política” que la UE busque acuerdos alternativos para minimizar las consecuencias del impacto del alza de aranceles decretada por Trump.

El presidente de Estados Unidos firmó el miércoles un decreto para lanzar una tarifa aduanera mínima del 10% para todas las importaciones que llegan al país, y del 20% para los productos procedentes de la UE.

La Comisión Europea ofreció a Estados Unidos un acuerdo para adoptar un arancel cero en el intercambio de bienes industriales.

Genevard aseguró que “la agricultura no debe ser una variable de ajuste de la respuesta”, ante el temor de que aumentar los aranceles a la soja estadounidense, que necesitan los ganaderos europeos, pase finalmente factura al sector y a los consumidores.

title: Pérdidas en soja paraguaya: ¿tienen impacto los aranceles de Trump? - (Published 7 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: El presidente de la Unión de Gremios de la Producción ratificó sus cálculos sobre pérdidas de más de 600 millones de dólares en la cosecha de soja de la actual temporada y analizó el impacto de las ta ...
resumen:
El presidente de la Unión de Gremios de la Producción (UGP), Héctor Cristaldo, ratificó sus cálculos sobre pérdidas de más de 600 millones de dólares en la cosecha de soja de la actual temporada.

Cristaldo estimó que la campaña sojera 2024/25 en Paraguay registraría pérdidas cerca de los 700 millones de dólares, atribuidas a una merma en la producción que calculó en un 15 por ciento.

Según sus cálculos, solo el menor volumen de producción resultaría en “520 millones de dólares menos de ingresos al país”, a lo que debe sumarse una reducción de los precios de mercado de la soja que resultarían en una pérdida adicional de 180 millones de dólares con relación al año pasado.

Cristaldo comentó sobre el impacto que los aranceles globales a importaciones anunciados por el gobierno de los Estados Unidos, bajo la administración de Donald Trump, tendrían en el mercado global y, por lo tanto, en los números de la soja paraguaya.

Señaló que los aranceles no han tenido un impacto “directo” sobre la producción paraguaya, pero indicó que la “volatilidad” que han generado podría impactar de manera indirecta.

Los aranceles llegan en abril, tradicionalmente el mes en que se cierra el mayor número de contratos.

title: What is a recession, and is it tied to stock market declines? What to know after Trump’s tariffs - (Published 10 hour(s), 4 minute(s) ago)
content: Stock markets have been falling, and the plunge accelerated after President Donald Trump unveiled wide-reaching U.S. tariffs. Here's what to know.
resumen:
Stock markets have been falling, and the plunge accelerated after President Donald Trump unveiled U.S. tariffs on virtually every country on April 2. Commenters on social media have said the drop in stock prices could portend a recession. Professional analysts at JPMorgan have estimated a 60% likelihood of a recession, while Goldman Sachs and Morningstar put the odds between 40% and 50%.

Several things tend to happen in recessions: business investment declines, unemployment rises, hours worked decline, and consumer purchases decline.

The arbiter of recessions is the National Bureau of Economic Research’s Business Cycle Dating Committee. The committee has been marking the start and end points of recessions for decades. It currently includes economists from Harvard, Princeton, Northwestern, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of California, Berkeley. The committee deliberates privately, and it takes a holistic approach. The factors it uses to determine the start of a recession are "a significant decline in economic activity that is spread across the economy and that lasts more than a few months." The most recent recession was from February 2020 to April 2020.

A common yardstick for determining whether a recession is underway is two consecutive quarters of declining gross domestic product. The committee officially weighs factors such as inflation-adjusted personal income, nonfarm payrolls, household employment data, inflation-adjusted personal expenditures, inflation-adjusted manufacturing and trade sales, and industrial production. Stock market declines are not included on this list.

Since 1950, the U.S. has experienced 10 official recessions. Seven were accompanied by declines in the Standard & Poors 500, while three were not. The average loss in the S&P 500 was about 31% in the seven recessions that accompanied stock market declines. The declines ranged from 18% to 55%, with the 55% drop occurring during the Great Recession. Since the end of January 2025, the S&P is down roughly 19%. The biggest stock market decline ever came during the Great Depression: Between August 1929 and July 1932, the S&P experienced an 88% loss.

If a recession does occur in the wake of Trump’s tariff decisions, it could have different attributes than other recessions. A recession could be accompanied by higher inflation. The phenomenon is called "stagflation" — a combination of economic stagnation and inflation. Another unusual feature of a tariff-driven recession could be its simultaneous global reach, given Trump’s decision to apply at least a 10% tariff on virtually every country in the world. This could lead to "a coordinated recession across the globe."

title: Aranceles sin fin neoliberal - (Published 19 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: Se cumplió el plazo para la imposición de aranceles por parte del que sigue siendo el país hegemón en el mundo: Estados Unidos. Y el gobierno de Donald Trump impuso un impuesto base de 10 por ciento, ...
resumen:
Se cumplió el plazo para la imposición de aranceles por parte de Estados Unidos. El gobierno de Donald Trump impuso un impuesto base de 10 por ciento, y aranceles diferenciados que afectan más a la región asiática. El neoliberalismo se estableció desde la década de 1970. El neoliberalismo implica la privatización de empresas, desregular medidas para favorecer al capital y liberalizar el comercio. Lo que se está presenciando no es el fin del neoliberalismo, en tanto que sólo se está trastocando el aspecto comercial. El ajuste estructural económico y político fue brutal desde los setenta y sin embargo no hubo incremento del desarrollo económico. Dos hechos históricos marcaron el siglo XX, la caída del muro de Berlín y de la exunión soviética. A partir de la década de los noventa el libre comercio se estableció como regla mundial y con éste la globalización. La globalización es un proceso de dominación y apropiación del mundo. Las condiciones del neoliberalismo impuestas por el Fondo Monetario Internacional y el Banco Mundial, incluían exensiones fiscales, mano de obra barata y tratados de libre comercio. Decir que es el fin del neoliberalismo es un reduccionismo a uno de los elementos de éste, el libre comercio. Donald Trump mostró que la manera de gobernar y de relacionarse con el mundo sería mediante amagos de aranceles. Trump y el trumpismo son expresión de la crisis orgánica, de la decadencia y el agotamiento del american way of life. A marzo de 2025, el Observatorio Venezolano Antibloqueo contabilizó 37 mil 875 Medidas Coercitivas Unilaterales (MUC) sobre 30 países. El 97 por ciento de estas medidas (36 mil 648) se concentran en nueve países y el 38 por ciento de las MUC son impuestas por Estados Unidos. El gobierno conservador de Donald Trump incrementa los aranceles a más de 180 países. No se salvaron ni las islas Malvinas, tampoco sus principales socios comerciales, ni aquellos con los que tiene Tratados de Libre Comercio, salvo dos: México y Canadá. El régimen de acumulación de capital impuesto desde 1970 terminó la segunda década del 2020 con datos alarmantes: estancamiento económico, pérdida de 6.5 millones de empleos desde 1979 hasta 2023 en la industria manufacturera, aumento de la concetración de la riqueza y por lo tanto, el aumento de la pobreza. En 2021 51 mil 700 adultos poseen el 6.4 por ciento, el 50 por ciento más pobre, 2.6 mil millones de personas poseían el 2 por ciento de la riqueza. La producción manufacturera de Estados Unidos como porcentaje mundial pasó del 28.4 por ciento en 2001 al 17.4 por ciento en 2023. La fabricación representa sólo el 11 por ciento del PIB de los Estados Unidos. El gobierno de Trump impuso aranceles al mundo, con la finalidad de abatir el déficit comercial que tiene con varios países.
México: Exportaciones 27.9 miles de millones de USD, Importaciones 41.7 miles de millones de USD, Porcentaje del comercio total 14.5%, Arancel impuesto 0%.

Datos a enero de 2025.
La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum el 3 de abril de 2025, frente a aranceles, lo importante fue el reconocimiento del T-MEC. El T-MEC será la punta de lanza para la reorganización comercial. El 75 por ciento de los componentes deben ser de contenido de valor regional, el 70 por ciento del acero y aluminio usado en la industria automotriz debe provenir de América del Norte, el 40 por ciento del valor del vehículo debe producirse con salarios de al menos 16 dólares la hora y las autopartes deben contener al menos un 75 por ciento del valor regional. La tasa arancelaria contra lo principales socios comerciales va en dos sentidos: reducir el déficit comercial existente y atraer inversiones al territorio estadunidense. Joe Biden publicó una gran cantidad de acuerdos y estrategias con varios países de América Latina, principalmente los miembros del CAFTA-DR (El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, República Dominicana) y varios países del Caribe. También estableció estrategias de protección económica, mares abiertos y acuerdos militares con varios países del Indopacífico. La guerra comercial contra China funcionó al reducir el déficit comercial, política que continuó Joe Biden.

title: Esto opina Moody´s sobre los retos crediticios ante aranceles anunciados por Trump - (Published 23 hour(s), 10 minute(s) ago)
content: El presidente de los Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, reaccionó a la advertencia de la Reserva Federal (FED) de las consecuencias por el aumento de aranceles, lo cual traerá más inflación y poco ...
resumen: Durante la presentación de perspectivas macroeconómicas para Guatemala por parte de la calificadora de riesgo Moody´s, se abordó el contexto actual para el país ante los aranceles anunciados por el presidente Donald Trump. Elisa Parisi-Capone, analista de Moody´s destacó algunos retos crediticios ante un panorama global, macroeconómico y geopolítico complejo. “Para Guatemala las vulnerabilidades son el comercio con Estados Unidos y la exposición a aranceles del 10%. Si vemos la dependencia comercial: más del 30% de las exportaciones de Guatemala son hacia EE.UU. y a pesar del déficit comercial que Guatemala tiene con EE.UU. los aranceles van a entrar en efecto”, explicó Parisi-Capone. Otro factor que analiza Moody´s es el tema de la migración de EE.UU. En ese sentido, habría una pérdida potencial de empleos para trabajadores guatemaltecos en sectores como la agricultura y la construcción en EE.UU. Un equipo de analistas de Moody´s presentó las perspectivas y retos para Guatemala. Esto podría afectar el flujo de remesas, que a la vez provocaría la reducción del consumo de los receptores de las remesas en Guatemala y así como afectaría el crecimiento económico y también la reducción de la competitividad, indicaron. Parisi-Capone, también se refirió a las políticas migratorias más restrictivas, como las deportaciones que podrían aumentar los desafíos sociales en Guatemala y necesitar un aumento del gasto social del gobierno. No obstante, se aclara quede momento no se ha observado una repercusión en las remesas. “De la primera administración de Trump, las remesas se quedaron muy fuertes, pero esta vez vamos a ver si esta dinámica va a continuar porque hay un clima de incertidumbre que es mayor que en el pasado”, explicó la analista. Puede ser que haya un impacto para el crecimiento, la incertidumbre lo vemos en los mercados. “Según unos estudios que nuestro equipo de macroeconomía ha preparado, el escenario de aranceles muy negativo para los países con más exposición más importante, vemos un impacto negativo del 0.3 hasta el 1%, es posible que haya un impacto para el crecimiento”, puntualizó Parisi-Capone. Los analistas de Moody´s, quienes visitaron Guatemala y ofrecieron una conferencia de prensa, aclararon que es necesario realizar un estudio a fondo del impacto que podría generar el tema de los aranceles.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Disastrous For Elon Musk - (Published 12 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: From Tesla to SpaceX to xAI, Elon Musk’s sprawling global business empire will be slammed by Trump’s tariffs regime. Here’s how.
resumen:
Elon Musk's global business empire, including Tesla, SpaceX, and xAI, will be negatively impacted by Trump's tariffs.

Tesla:
*   Tesla's stock has fallen 17% since the tariff announcement.
*   Tesla relies on global supply chains, importing 20-25% of car parts from foreign suppliers (excluding Canada).
*   40% of Tesla's electric battery materials come from Chinese suppliers.
*   Escalating U.S.-China tensions could hamper Tesla's efforts to receive approval from Chinese officials for self-driving vehicles and eliminate a ban on Teslas from entering military complexes and facilities.
*   Musk's association with the Trump administration may tarnish the brand's appeal to Chinese buyers.
*   Tesla is better positioned than many U.S. rivals to cope with the tariffs because its gigafactories in Austin and California produce all of the Tesla vehicles it sells to American consumers.

SpaceX:
*   SpaceX faces rising costs across its supply chain and unhappy international clients.
*   SpaceX relies on foreign suppliers for raw materials and parts.
*   Starlink accounted for $8.2 billion of SpaceX’s $13.1 billion of revenue last year.
*   SpaceX relies heavily on Asian manufacturers.
*   Tariffs on Vietnam may disrupt SpaceX’s planned operations there.
*   SpaceX relies on raw materials and rare earth metals.
*   SpaceX has to worry about how foreign governments view Trump, and by extension Musk.

xAI:
*   xAI will face rising costs and supply chain disruptions.
*   Data centers in the U.S. rely on parts from abroad, especially from China, Taiwan, and Vietnam.
*   xAI will have to contend with the rising costs of commodities, such as steel and aluminum.

title: La UE saca el bourbon de la primera ronda de aranceles de hasta un 25% que impondrá a EEUU - (Published 12 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Será la primera represalia a la guerra arancelaria lanzada por la Administración Trump y que la UE empezará a recaudar de manera escalonada ...
resumen:
La UE saca el bourbon de la primera ronda de aranceles de hasta un 25% que impondrá a EEUU.
La Comisión Europea ha sacado el bourbon y el vino de la de aranceles de hasta un 25% que activará a partir del 15 de abril a importaciones procedentes de Estados Unidos.
Será la primera represalia a la guerra arancelaria lanzada por la Administración Trump y que la UE empezará a recaudar de manera escalonada en tres fases --abril, mayo y diciembre--.
El comisario de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, circuló la propuesta entre las capitales en la tarde del lunes, al término una reunión extraordinaria con los ministros de Comercio de la UE en Luxemburgo.
El documento será sometido a votación este miércoles, 9 de abril, en una reunión de técnicos de los Veintisiete con el objetivo de que pueda entrar en vigor ya el 14 de abril.
Una primera fase, la que se basa en el primer catálogo de productos gravados en la crisis anterior de 2018 y de la que se ha excluido el bourbon, se aplique desde el 15 de abril.
Bruselas revisa su propuesta de inicio tras "escuchar" a las capitales, según dijo Sefcovic.
Se trata de un gesto hacia Trump.
El resto de la lista, a la que Bruselas ha incorporado nuevos productos para alcanzar el mismo nivel de impacto que Estados Unidos generará con sus aranceles al acero y aluminio europeos, se podrá empezar a recaudar a partir del 16 de mayo, a excepción de los contingentes de soja y almendras que quedarán para el 1 de diciembre.
La represalia a los aranceles del 25% al acero y aluminio europeos no llegaría al nivel máximo de impacto de 26.000 millones de euros que Bruselas estimó inicialmente.
La propuesta prevé recargos de entre el 10 y el 25% sobre una gama muy diversa de productos, parte de ellos, los que se aplicarán desde abril, basados en el catálogo utilizado en 2018 y 2020, con un valor estimado de hasta 8.000 millones.
Los servicios comunitarios estimaron que podrían tener un impacto de hasta 18.000 millones de euros.
Estas contramedidas responden únicamente a los primeros aranceles de Trump al acero y al aluminio.

title: Carga con todo contra una nación: Donald Trump le subió los aranceles a este país hasta el 104% - (Published Apr 8, 2025)
content: Donald Trump decidió elevar los aranceles a un país en particular hasta el 104% debido a sus represalias. De acuerdo a Fox Business, este nuevo porcentaje se estaría aplicando a partir de esta mediano ...
resumen:
Donald Trump decidió elevar los aranceles a China hasta el 104% a partir de esta medianoche, debido a las represalias de Pekín tras los incrementos arancelarios del 34% iniciales de hace unos días. Un portavoz de la Casa Blanca informó a la cadena Fox Business.
Trump ya había adelantado esta semana que si China no retiraba su batería de aranceles recíprocos del 34% para el mediodía de hoy, implementaría a partir de la medianoche de este martes otra subida del 50% que haría que las exportaciones del gigante asiático tengan un incremento hasta el 104%.
Edward Lawrence, periodista de Fox Business, citó a la portavoz de la Casa Blanca (Karoline Leavitt), este nuevo incremento contra China entraría en vigor un minuto después de la medianoche de este martes; vale decir, el miércoles 9 de abril.
El gobierno chino expresó su “firme condena” por la nueva subida de aranceles hasta el 104%, a la que calificaron de “naturaleza chantajista” de la administración Trump.
China replicó una serie de contramedidas a los aranceles anunciados la semana pasada por Trump, que elevaron las tarifas a los productos chinos hasta al menos el 54%.
Entre las medidas adoptadas por China se incluyen aranceles del 34% sobre las importaciones provenientes de Estados Unidos, sanciones a varias empresas estadounidenses, restricciones a la exportación de ciertos minerales raros, y la suspensión de la importación de productos de pollo y sorgo de algunas compañías norteamericanas. Además, se iniciaron investigaciones antimonopolio y antidumping contra empresas y productos estadounidenses. China también presentó una demanda ante la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC) contra Estados Unidos por los “aranceles recíprocos” aplicados a sus socios comerciales, en el marco del mecanismo de solución de disputas.

title: CNN Exclusive: This Asian leader is taking a very different approach from China over Trump’s tariff war - (Published 11 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: South Korea will not follow China in fighting back against tariffs imposed by the United States, its leader told CNN in an exclusive interview on Tuesday, as he touted plans to try to secure a deal ...
resumen: South Korean Acting President Han Duck-soo stated South Korea will not follow China in fighting back against tariffs imposed by the United States in an exclusive interview with CNN. He touted plans to secure a deal with President Donald Trump. South Korea faces 25% tariffs as part of Trump’s global tariffs rollout this week. Han said South Korea “clearly would like to negotiate” with the US and praised the two countries’ “very strong alliance.” He stated, “We will not take that route” when asked if South Korea might band together with other countries like Japan or China to push back against the US tariffs. Han said, “I don’t think that kind of fighting back will improve the situation dramatically,” downplaying the significance of a recent meeting between the trade ministers of the three Asian nations. Han spoke with Trump on the phone, which Trump described as a “great call” in a post on Truth Social. Han was tapped as acting president in December after former leader Yoon Suk Yeol was impeached and removed from office. Han was impeached two weeks later and reinstated in late March. The latest measures follow an earlier 25% tariff on steel and aluminum, imposed last month, which will hit South Korea hard as the fourth-largest exporter of steel to the US. That’s in addition to a separate 25% levy on US imports of cars and auto parts. Han described the US tariffs as “a pity,” acknowledging that “not everything will be solved in a day or two” and that South Korean businesses should brace for impact. He voiced optimism, saying he believed the two countries can reach a resolution before factory lines start closing across Korea. Han seeks an off-ramp, not retaliation. Han said, “I think we should, in a very cool way, assess what this kind of 25% means for us, and we should, in a very cool way, negotiate with them,” adding he had already dispatched his trade minister to Washington. Han has been working in the government since the 1970s, with deep expertise on economics. He repeatedly referenced the last major global trade war in the early 1930s. Han said, “In game theory, just doing things individually may not help the situation to improve. We should communicate, cooperate and work together. I think we should try to find a win-win situation.” South Korea is America’s sixth-largest trading partner, with total trade in goods and services reaching $197 billion in 2024. Last year, Korean exports to the US hit a record high of $128 billion. The US trade deficit with South Korea also surged, reaching $66 billion in 2024. Trump said, “We can make a really fair deal … a good deal for the United States, not a good deal for others.” Senior Trump trade advisor Peter Navarro wrote: “This is not a negotiation. For the US, it is a national emergency triggered by trade deficits caused by a rigged system.” China has positioned itself as an oppositional force standing up to what it called American “bullying.” The meeting between Japan, South Korea, and China drew attention due to its timing, just before Trump’s tariff announcement. At $133 billion, Korean exports to China last year exceeded even those to the US. Han insisted that the trilateral meeting “was not a very extraordinary one, it was a normal meeting.” He added that the trio often hold ministerial meetings. Han said that kind of response could “really contract global trade.”

title: How Trump tariffs are impacting trucking - (Published 10 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: When economy-shaking tax practices flip several times a month, it can be hard to follow. Here is the latest news on Trump's tariffs and how the trucking industry and ...
resumen:
On April 8, 2025, FleetOwner reported on how Trump's tariffs are impacting the trucking industry and commercial vehicle markets.

A snap poll FleetOwner ran online the weekend after Trump announced the global import duties found that more than half of transportation industry respondents said they expect the trade taxes to impact their business negatively; 30% said they expect positive impacts.

President Trump signed an executive order implementing sweeping tariffs on nearly all imports on Wednesday afternoon, April 2. The U.S. will impose a baseline duty tax of 10% on all imports, with some exemptions, beginning April 5. On April 9, Trump will impose varying duties on imports from 57 specific countries as much as 49%. In his speech from the White House Rose Garden, Trump said he is imposing a 25% tariff on all foreign-made automobiles (excluding heavy-duty trucks), which was announced on March 26 and took effect April 3.

President Donald Trump’s newly implemented sweeping tariffs going into effect in April could reset global trade and domestic supply chains.

President Donald Trump issued sweeping 25% tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports to the U.S.—but not before threatening and then quickly revoking an extreme 50% tariff on Canadian steel and aluminum.

President Donald Trump, once again, postponed tariffs on most goods imported from Canada and Mexico. Under the latest supply chain shakeup, several goods under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement—including automotive products—are exempt from Trump’s wide-ranging 25% tariffs for at least one month.

Beginning just after midnight on March 4, imports from Canada and Mexico will be taxed at 25%; Canadian energy imports get a 10% tax; and Chinese imports that were levied with a 10% tariff in February, now face 20% duties.

In February, China faced only an additional 10% tariff but countered the levy with its own retaliatory tariffs. The country said it would implement a 15% tariff on coal and liquefied natural gas products and a 10% tariff on crude oil, agricultural machinery, and large-engine cars, according to the Associated Press. The tariffs are set to take effect on Monday.

President Trump is enacting major tariffs against Canada, Mexico, and China, taxing imports from those nations by 10% to 25%. Canada and Mexico have vowed to enact retaliatory tariffs.

Automotive manufacturers are monitoring how the new president and Congress will shape international trade. Tariffs and major trade agreements have potential to disrupt the U.S. commercial vehicle market.

Possible tariff scenarios are one of the number one issues for members of the Motor & Equipment Manufacturers Association, according to Ana Meuwissen, SVP of government affairs for MEMA.

In a Stifel freight forecast presentation, Jason Miller, Eli Broad professor of supply chain management at Michigan State, outlined the current freight environment and forecasted possible outcomes. Miller said, "If these higher rates stay in place, you know, longer than three months, I don't see how we don't end up in a recession within six months."

ACT Research President Ken Vieth, Josh Fisher, Bob Costello, American Trucking Associations chief economist, and Jose Guerrero, director of U.S. customs operations for Uber Freight, are also mentioned.

title: Trump threatens Milei: IMF loan only comes out with total submission - (Published 8 hour(s), 0 minute(s) ago)
content: Trump’s counselor says Washington would withdraw Buenos Aires loan request to the IMF if he reinforced China’s “position” in Argentina One of US President Donald ...
resumen: Donald Trump's counselor, Mauricio Claver Carone, stated that Washington's support for Argentina's negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) depends on Argentina distancing itself from China, specifically ending a swap agreement with Beijing. Claver Carone described Milei as an ally but emphasized that Washington's priority is to prevent any new agreement with the IMF from reinforcing China's position in Argentina. The swap agreement with China, renewed in June 2024 and worth about $5 billion, is crucial for Argentina, providing access to Renminbi that can be converted into dollars, reinforcing foreign reserves. Argentina is negotiating a $20 billion loan from the IMF under a new 10-year program. US support is crucial as Washington is the largest shareholder of the IMF. Milei's team met with Secretary of State Marco Rubio, but no concrete commitment was made. Argentina was also affected by the 10% global import tariff announced by the White House. Milei softened his anti-China stance in office, seeking to improve relations with China. Patricio Giusto, director of the Sino-Argentine Observatory, said Claver Carone's demand was unrealistic, given Argentina's financial restrictions and geopolitical needs. Milei is due to travel to China in May to attend the China-Celac Forum.

content: Tegucigalpa. – Con Inácio Lula da Silva, Claudia Sheinbaum, Gustavo Petro, Bernardo Arévalo, Yamandú Orsi, Miguel Díaz-Canel y Xiomara Castro, la IX Cumbre de la CELAC se perfila como una reunión con ...
resumen: La IX Cumbre de la CELAC en Tegucigalpa se perfila como una reunión con fuerte impronta de izquierda, con la participación de Inácio Lula da Silva, Claudia Sheinbaum, Gustavo Petro, Bernardo Arévalo, Yamandú Orsi, Miguel Díaz-Canel y Xiomara Castro. La cumbre estará marcada por el progresismo, el debate sobre nuevos pactos regionales y la incógnita de las ausencias y algunos presidentes que van de salida. Xiomara Castro traspasará la presidencia pro témpore de la CELAC a Gustavo Petro. La cumbre buscará enfrentar desafíos globales como el cambio climático, el narcotráfico y la migración. Se prevén diferencias políticas y distanciamientos entre los países del foro, incluyendo asuntos fuera de la región como la situación en la Franja de Gaza, y a nivel bilateral y de bloques, como ocurre en América del Sur y Centroamérica, o la situación en Venezuela. Se suman problemas como el descontento social, altos niveles de desempleo, pobreza, violencia criminal, corrupción, deficientes sistemas de salud, educación y justicia, y violaciones a los derechos humanos, o situaciones muy graves como la de Haití. Lula da Silva propondrá que la CELAC presente una candidatura única a la Secretaría General de la ONU, que será renovada en 2026. No se prevé la asistencia de Gabriel Boric, de Chile, y Luis Arce, de Bolivia. De los 33 países que integran la CELAC, solo 11 han confirmado su asistencia. Donald Trump anunció la imposición de un «arancel recíproco» del 10 % a todas las importaciones procedentes de los países de la región, con excepción de Venezuela y Nicaragua, que enfrentarán tasas más elevadas, del 15 % y el 18 %, respectivamente. A los miembros de la Comunidad del Caribe (Caricom) también les impuso un 10 % general, excepto Guyana, con un 38 %. Los presidentes que han confirmado su participación son Gustavo Petro, de Colombia; Luis Arce, de Bolivia; Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, de Brasil; Miguel Díaz-Canel, de Cuba; Yamandú Orsi, de Uruguay; Claudia Sheinbaum, de México; Bernardo Arévalo, de Guatemala, y Leslie Voltaire, mandatario provisional de Haití. Se suman los primeros ministros de Belice, Juan Antonio Briceño; de Guyana, Mark Anthony Phillips, y de San Vicente y las Granadinas, Ralph Gonsalves. Las medidas migratorias y arancelarias impuestas por Trump afectarán a todos los países. El analista Omar García indicó que la CELAC debería abordar el tema de los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos.

resumen:
La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum confirmó que mañana estará en la inauguración y en la primera plenaria de la Cumbre de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC) en Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Dijo que después de la plenaria regresará a México y que su participación obedece a una invitación personal de la presidenta hondureña Xiomara Castro, y que aprovechará la ocasión para hablar sobre la necesidad de fortalecer los lazos políticos, culturales y económicos de la región.

Donald Trump, en su nueva ofensiva proteccionista, ha impuesto aranceles a prácticamente todos los países de América Latina y el Caribe: un 10% a la mayoría, pero con castigos más severos a Nicaragua (18%), Venezuela (15%) y Guyana (38%). México, aunque cubierto parcialmente por el T-MEC, enfrenta un arancel del 25% en productos que no entran en este tratado.

title: Maduro prepara decreto de emergencia económica para blindar a Venezuela de los aranceles de Trump - (Published 15 hour(s), 57 minute(s) ago)
content: CARACAS (AP) — El presidente venezolano Nicolás Maduro anunció el lunes que se dispone a decretar una “emergencia económica” que le otorgaría poderes ...
resumen: El presidente venezolano Nicolás Maduro anunció el lunes que se dispone a decretar una “emergencia económica” que le otorgaría poderes especiales para enfrentar la crisis que, según él, se avecina en el mundo a consecuencia de la imposición del gobierno de Donald Trump de un arancel base mundial de 10% y tasas arancelarias mayores para decenas de países que tienen superávits comerciales con Estados Unidos. El decreto también apuntaría a enfrentar los efectos de las nuevas sanciones estadounidenses impuestas a Venezuela. Maduro declaró en su programa semanal de televisión que el martes firmaría el decreto constitucional de emergencia económica para proteger y defender la economía de toda Venezuela. Mediante la declaratoria de emergencia económica, el mandatario busca asumir “funciones especiales, constitucionales, extraordinarias para avanzar en la defensa de la economía venezolana, en su impulso”, y tener instrumentos “para salir airosos frente a todas las circunstancias previsibles”, incluida la incertidumbre económica mundial. Los mercados globales se desplomaron al día siguiente del anuncio de Trump, y experimentaron una caída aún mayor después que China anunció que tomaría represalias con aranceles semejantes. Maduro hizo su anuncio casi dos semanas después que Trump anunciara nuevas sanciones a las exportaciones de petróleo venezolano, entre las que destaca la imposición de aranceles de 25% sobre todas las importaciones de cualquier país que adquiera petróleo o gas a Venezuela. Recientemente, Trump también anunció la imposición de aranceles de 15% al país sudamericano. En marzo, el Departamento del Tesoro de Estados Unidos formalizó el fin de la licencia que permitía al gigante energético Chevron Corp. operar en Venezuela. La economía venezolana acusa un marcado declive desde octubre pasado, que se espera se acentúe con la imposición de las nuevas sanciones estadounidenses. El tipo de cambio oficial, que se mantuvo artificialmente en aproximadamente 36 bolívares por dólar, a partir del 24 de octubre pasado casi se duplicó debido al incremento en el gasto público. El resultado fue una depreciación acelerada del bolívar y el alza del tipo de cambio oficial y el mercado paralelo. La suspensión de la licencia de Chevron tuvo un impacto directo en la oferta de divisas. El Observatorio Venezolano de Finanzas estima que la inflación acumulada en el primer trimestre del año se ubicó en 36,1 %, mientras que la variación interanual alcanzó el 136%. Washington comenzó a intensificar las sanciones contra Venezuela tras la primera reelección de Maduro en 2018.
